KENCOT. Depositions of the abbot and convent of Oseney in a tithe cause between them and sir William, rector of Kencote, concerning two parts of the tithe of corn arising from the whole of the demesne of sir Roger de Heyli, kt., in Kencote. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 377.

Indenture between the abbot and convent of Oseney of one part, and John Bavel of Kencot of the other, by which the abbot and convent demise to John their portion of the tithes of Kencot for 17 years, paying annually for the same 6s. 8d. Dated on the vigil of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 25 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 378.

KIDLINGTON. Grant from Hugh de Plessetis to William the abbot of Oseney of 5s. annual rent, in frankalmoigne, from tenements in Cudelinton. Walter Croxford confirms to William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, the above bequest of 5s. by Hugh de Plessetis. [Hugh de Plessetis ob. 1291, William (1267)]. [Copy on one slip and the two deeds, made early by 15th cent., or late in 14th.]
MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 379.

William, son of Elyas, formerly the miller of Cudlinton, grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, a fishery in Charewelle with appurtenances. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 381.

KIDLINGTON. Robert le ... gives and confirms to ... two acres of arable land ... and one acre of meadow which is called Stockmede. Thomas de Kidlingtone a witness. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 382.
Fragment of the plea of a proctor before a judge concerning the tithes of Kidlington. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 383.

Alice, relict of William, son of Elyas, formerly the miller of Cudelintone, quit-claims to Oseney her right in the lands and tenements in the village of Cudelinton which the said William her husband had there. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 384.

Thomas Puteslo, vicar of Cudelyngton, and John Havyl, grant to John the abbot and convent of Oseney a messuage and ... virgates of land in ... com. Oxon. Dated .... January, 10 Ric. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 385.
Thomas ... grants to the abbot and convent of Oseney ... which land is of the fee of the prior of Bur ... (? Bicester). Dated at Oxford ... [Fragment.] (c. 1400) (On paper.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 386.

Bond in £200 entered into by Laurence Stubbs, late vicar of Cudlington, with the abbot and convent of Oseney, to discharge all claims that may arise for one year in Cudlington. Dated 10 July, 6 Henry VIII and agreed by Stubbs. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 387a.

KIDLINGTON, SWERFORD, and SENEWELL. W[alter de Gray], archbishop of York, master R[anulf] de Warham, official of Norwich, and master R., archdeacon of Gypewic, executors of the will of John de Gray, bishop of Norwich, assign to the church and canons of St. Mary of Oseney, a certain wood which is called Coggeswode pertaining to the village of Kedelinton, and the church of Swereford with the chapel of Senwell, left to Oseney by the said bishop in his last will who had them by the gift of sir Henry de Oylly. (c. 1217-18.) [Walter de Gray, 1218; John de Gray, ob. 1214.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 387b.

KIDLINGTON and HOOKNORTON. Henry de Oylly grants to the church and canons of St. Mary, Oseney, for the health of his soul and the souls of his predecessors and successors, especially for the soul of Sibil his wife and Matilda his daughter, 100s., of annual rent, for which he has assigned to them 60s., which he was accustomed to receive annually from his mill of Cudelington, and the homage and service of Elyas the miller and his heirs; also he gives to them in his same manor, in frankalmoigne, one virgate of land, namely, that which Ralph Riveling held, with a messuage and croft and with all that appertains to it within and without the village; also he gives to the said canons in his manor of Hokenorton one mark of silver, which Robert Bernard was accustomed to pay annually for three virgates of land in the same village; also he gives to them 8s. sterling, which Roger Olycrance was accustomed annually to pay to him for half a hide of land, which he had with Matilda his wife, daughter of Philip the clerk, and held of the said Henry in the same manor with the homages and services of the said Robert Bernard and Roger Olycrance and their heirs; also he gives to the same canons in his manor of Hokenorton, one meadow which is called Cuham, in frankalmoigne. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Roger abbot of Dorchester, Robert de Aumari, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 380.

KILTEVENAN, Ireland. Roger de Wiricestria grants to William Exonia and his heirs the whole of the village of Kilmacliuie for an annual rent of 2s., paid to him at Kilstevenan, within the octave of St. John the Baptist. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 229.

Ascot near Stadhampton. Conveyance by Michael Dormer, esq., of Hampton Poyle, co. Oxon., of the manor of Askott, with appurtenances, in the parish of Milton, to Thomas Bodley, esq., of London, and William Gente, esq., of London in trust for the said Michael Dormer and Dorothy his wife, and their heirs, for ever. Dated 7 May, 36 Eliz. (1594). Signed Michael Dormer. (The seal is lost.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 230.
Caversham. Court roll of the manor of Caversham. Held by John Dalby for John, earl of Kildare, on Monday, Oct. 16, 1704. MS. Rolls Oxon. 62.

Convention between William, canon, and proctor general of the abbot and canons of Oseney, and Robert de Vadis, by which he leases to the said Robert for his life the church of Kiltevenan to farm, paying annually to the canons of Oseney or their assigns 2s. (c. 1216-26.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 230.

Roger, son of Robert Kerdif of Kiltevenan, chaplain, grants for 30 years, to the abbot and convent of Oseney and brother Walter Hilmden their proctor at Kiltevenan 3 1/2 acres of arable land in the field of Kiltevenan, as security for payment of 16 marks, at an annual rent of 7d. Dated 25 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 231.

Sentence by Thomas ...sethe, deputy ("visitator") of master Robert de Bermyngham, official of the see of Cashel, by which the abbot and convent of Oseney are confirmed in their claim of an annual pension of 5s. Signed John Otulyn, vicar of ... . Dated at Fythard on the vigil of Trinity Sunday 1316. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 232.

Public instrument made in a chapter held at Oseney before Henry de Elsham, notary public, Thomas, abbot of Oseney, and others concerning a vacancy caused by the resignation of William Moye, in the church of Kiltevenan, Cassell diocese. Dated June 30 ("Junii die ultima"), 1360. [Mutilated and partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 233.

KIRTLINGTON. Master John Cottesford, son and heir of sir Roger Cottesford, kt., quit-claims to the abbot and convent of Oseney all his right in certain lands, rents, meadows, fisheries, etc. in Kirtlington (?). Dated at ... 12 Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 389.

LANGEPORT, co. Bucks. William, son of the late William le Barbour, of Oxford, quit-claims to Thomas, the abbot of Oseney, all demands relative to his lands and tenements in Langeport, co. Bucks, [while he was a minor]. Dated at Oseney on the feast ..., 17 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 161.

LAUNTON. John Hawkysford, rector of Lawnton, is bound to the abbot of Oseney in a sum of twenty pounds to pay such duties, as he was taxed unto by John, bishop of Lincoln. Dated 23 October, 16 Henry VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 390.

LEDHALE. Convention made between Stephen de Ledhale and Richard his eldest son of the one part, and sir Richard, the abbot, and convent of Oseney of the other, viz. that they have delivered to the same canons for a term of 8 years, which commenced on the vigil of the Ascension, 1226, the whole of their land of Ledhale with appurtenances, except their court and garden, to cultivate for half of the profit ('Wannag') of the same land each year to be taken by the said Stephen and his heirs. And they will reap and collect their half of the corn in autumn and the canons likewise their half. And the canons shall have 2 parts of the meadow of the said Stephen, and he and his heirs shall have the third part. Dated at Oseney, vigil of the Ascension, 1226. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 391.

LUDWELL. Charter reciting an inquisition taken on St. Bartholomew's day, 1257, as to the ancient right of the abbot and convent of Oseney in the parish of Wottone to two parts of the tithes of the demesne lordship of Ludewell of the honour of Wallingford, belonging to the church of St. George in the castle of Oxford, and the rector of Wotton to the third part of the tithes of the same lordship. Dated at Oseney, vigil of St. Giles, 1257. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 392.

William Bronne of Broghton in co. Oxon, heir of the late Joan Bronne, grants to William Reve of Rolandryght all his lands and messuages which came to him after the death of the said Joan, in Ledwell. Dated at Ledwell, 13 Oct., 25 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 393.

John Bronne of Salford, son and heir of John Bronne of Bereford, deceased, constitutes Walter Fox of Ledwell and John Whytesyld of Great Rollandryght his attornies, to give seisin in his name to William Reve of Rollandryght of all lands in Ledwell, lately called Bertwayes lond, and formerly Chapeleynes, which came to him as heir of John Bronne deceased. Dated at Salford, 3 Jan., 37 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 394.

William Reve of Rolandryght quit-claims to John Walton, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, all right in one messuage and one croft with a virgate of land in Ledewell, co. Oxon. Dated at Ledewell, 14 October, 11 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 395.

LONDON. Margery, daughter of Stephen Nicholas, quit-claims to Roger, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, all her right in all edifices, lands, and tenements, which the said abbot and convent have in the suburbs of the city of London, viz. in the parish of St. Sepulchre's beyond Newgate, to be published in "pleno hustengo London". (c. 1285-95.) Witn. Will. de Farendon, alderman, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 235.

Indenture by which a covenant is made between John, son of Adam de Kent, citizen, and "sackere" of London, of one part, and Richard, brother of the said John, of the other, concerning two tenements in the parish of St. Sepulchre's, London, demised to the said Richard. Dated at London, ... after the conversion of St. Paul, 9 Ed. II(?). (date partially lost). [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 236.

The will of Joan le Sackere, formerly wife of John le Sackere, sen., citizen of London. Dated London, Monday before feast of St. [Luke the evangelist] 1347. (See Sharpe, Calendar of wills proved and endrolled in the Court of Husting, London, A.D. 1258-A.D. 1688 (1889), vol. I, p. 510.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 237.

Thomas le Sackere, son of John le Sackere of London, quit-claims for himself and heirs to John de Hoxwode, sen., and Nicholas his son and Joan his wife, all his right in tenements, &c. in St. Sepulchre's, London. Dated at London the Sunday next after the feast of the Ascension, 22 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 238.
The admission of Henry Dymnell, brewer to the freedom of the city of London the Wednesday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 23 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 239.

The will of Henry Dymnell, citizen of London, dated at London in parish of St. Sepulchre, 1381, 4 September. [Mutilated.] (See Sharpe, Calendar of wills proved and endrolled in the Court of Husting, London, A.D. 1258-A.D. 1688 (1889), vol. II, pp. 225-26.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 240.
The will of Henry Dymenel, citizen of London, dated 4 Sept., 1381. [Duplicate, for probate.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 241.

Edward Madison, merchant of the Staple, Calais, and Joan his wife, formerly wife of Morgan Williams, deceased, acknowledges to have received of the abbot of Oseney 5 marks sterling of a certain annual rent of 20 marks, payable for the lives of the said Morgan and Joan. Dated in the church of St. Thomas of Acon, 2 Nov., 18 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 242.

MAIDS MORTON. The award of Roger, abbot of Abingdon, in a dispute between the abbot and convent of Oseney, and Walter Fitz-Nigel, concerning a certain hide of land in Morton; the said Walter to hold the same of the church of Oseney at an annual rent of 9s. (Roger, abbot, 1175-84.) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 162.

Convention made between Robert, parson of the church of St. Edmund of Morton, and sir William, son of Reginald of the same village, concerning the chapel in the court of the said William de Morton, namely, that the said Robert, with the assent of Walter de Morton, patron of the church, has granted to William and his heirs that they may have a chapel in his court of Morton to celebrate divine service for ever for himself, his heirs, their wives and families, without prejudice to the mother church, saving certain tithes, &c. For which concession the said William granted in frankalmoigne certain land (three acres) in Morton. (1220-1225.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 164.

Henry, son of Ralph Dayrel, confirms to William, son of Reginald, son of Assur de Morton, pannage for 30 pigs in his woods at Lillingastan, paying annually at Easter for the same one pair of white gloves. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 163.

Richard le Frankelein of Morton grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his homage and service, and for 60s. sterling paid to him, four acres of land and three roods of meadow in the field of Morton, paying annually to him and his heirs 6d. (c. 1230-40.) Witn. sir William Fitz-Reginald, Reginald his son, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 171.

Elyas le Droys of Morton and Alina his wife grant to sir Matthew, archdeacon of Bucks, for his service and for 40s. in hand paid, five acres of land in Morton, paying annually for the same one rose at the octave of St. John Bapt., for all secular services, &c. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 177.

Helyas le Drueys, with the consent of Alina his wife, grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his homage and service, three acres of land in Morton with appurtenances, paying to them and their heirs annually 1d. at Easter, for all services and demands. (c. 1230.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 176.

Elyas de Droys and Alina his wife grant to Robert de Torneberg (Thornbury), clerk, for his homage and service, four acres of land in Morton, paying annually for the same 1d., and for this donation and concession 20s. (c. 1230-40.) Witn. Sir William Fitz-Reginald, Reginald his son, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 178.

Elyas le Drueys of Morton, with the assent of Alina his wife, grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his service and for 30s. sterling, one messuage with appurtenances in Morton, which Herbert held of them, and is between the messuage of the said Henry and the messuage of Robert Wodecoc; paying annually to them and their heirs 1d. (c. 1230.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 174.
Peter of the mill grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his homage and service, a virgate of land in Morton with messuages and ... (c. 1230.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 168.

Robert, formerly rector of Morton, grants to Henry, son of Robert,
and Nich[ola] his wife, for their service, and 40s. sterling, one messuage in Morton, viz. that which belongs to that virgate of land which Herbert sometime held; paying annually to the church of Morton to the altar of St. Edmund 1/2d. for all services, (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 169.

Sir Walter de Morthon, kt., grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his homage and service and one mark, one messuage with appurtenances in the village of Morthon, namely that which Reginald le Bunt formerly held, paying annually one clove at Easter. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Will., son of Reginald de Morthone, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 173.

Convention made between William, son of Reginald de Morton, of the one part, and Walter, son of Richard de Morton, of the other, namely that the said William grants a licence to Walter to inclose his wood of Morton, in which he claimed common, saving to William and his heirs common for his pigs between the feasts of St. Michael and St. Martin. (c. 1230.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 165.

Matthew de Stratton, archdeacon of Bucks, grants to the church of St. Mary, Oseney, and to Richard the abbot and canons there, for the health of his own and parents' souls, and also for Henry, son of Robert, formerly his seneschal, and of Nichola his wife, 13 acres, 1 rood of arable land and 1 1/2 rood of meadow in the fields of Morthon, and the whole of his court with gardens and 40 buttes in a pasture to the north of his garden, which he had by the gift of William, son of sir Reginald, together with other parcels of land, &c. in Morthon, Borthon, Adinthon, Sevenhampton, Cloppelai, and Witteleia. (c. 1255-65.) [Richard, abbot 1254-67.] [Slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 179.

Walter de Morton grants to Matthew de Stratton, archdeacon of Bucks, for his homage and service, one virgate of land in Morton, also the homage and service of William de Bayus, viz. 2s. rent and all escheats that will fall to him and his heirs; to hold the same for ever at an annual rent of one pound of pepper, or 6d. For this donation the said Matthew gave him 20 marks of silver, (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 175.

Robert, rector of the church of Morton, grants to Henry, son of Robert, for half a mark of silver, one half acre of land in the fields of Morton, paying annually to him and his heirs 1/2d. (c. 1230.) Witn. Sir Will. Fitz-Reginald, Reginald his son, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 172.

William, son of William, son of sir Reginald de Morton, kt., grants to the church and canons of St. Mary's, Oseney, in frankalmoigne, a messuage, curtilage and croft, situated between a house of the said abbot and canons, and William son of Walter the clerk, with 8 1/2 acres of arable land in the fields and village of Morton. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 167.

Robert de Morton, son and heir of Mabilia, daughter of Walter Burga, quit-claims to the church, abbot Richard and canons of St. Mary's, Oseney, the donation which Matthew de Stratton, archdeacon of Bucks, made to them, of one hide of land with garden and wood in Morton. (c. 1255-65.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 166 .

Walter de Morton grants to Henry, son of Robert, for his homage and service, the whole of his meadow and pasture in the field of
Morton, paying annually 1d. for all services; for this grant the said Henry gave 9 marks of silver. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 170.

Final concord, dated Oct. of St John the Baptist, 47 Hen. III, between Matthew de Stratton, archdeacon of Bucks, and Elyas le Droys and Alina his wife, concerning one messuage, one virgate, and 14 acres of land in [Morton]. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 180.
Small defaced fragment of the will of Matthew de Stratton, archdeacon of Buckingham. Dated 1268. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 181.
Tattered fragment of a manor court roll. Temp. Ed. II. (c. 1300?) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 182.

MESSEWORTH and CLOPEHAM. Certificate by the dean of Bedford of receipt of a mandate addressed to the prior and sub-prior of St. Oswald's, Gloucester, sub-delegates, directing him to warn the prior and convent of Caldwell to pay certain sums of money adjudged due to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for tithes of Messeworth and Clopeham and costs, under pain of excommunication. Dated at Gloucester the Wednesday next after the feast of the Apostles Peter and Paul, 1279. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 22.
MIXBURY. Fragment of a list of charters and from time of empress Matilda to Henry IV belonging to the manor of Mixbury and elsewhere. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 397.

Mandate from the King (Ed. II) reciting a writ dated London, 23 Aug. the 5th of his reign, commanding the sheriff to cause a respite to be made in a suit between John, parson of Mixbury, and the abbot of Oseney and others, which respite is now to be ended if the said abbot and others petition for it. Richard de Polampton, sheriff, [9 and 10 Ed. II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 398.

An agreement between the abbot and convent of Oseney, and James Job, rector of Mixbury, concerning an annual pension of 40s., and the parish of St. Michael of Fullw.
[Mutilated and defaced.] Temp. Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 401.

MIXBURY, NEWTON PURCELL, and HAMPTON GAY. Transcript in 14th century of the composition between Oseney and Edmund, earl of Cornwall, concerning 2 1/2 knights' fees in Mixbury, Niweton Purcell, and Hampton Gay. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 396.

NORTHBROOK. An agreement by sir John de Cherburch, knt., who had been summoned by the abbot and convent of Oseney,
that his servants should in future gather to his barn the tithe wheat of the lordship of Norbroc according to the ancient custom of the place, to await the coming of the tithing man, and not leave it in the field to the injury of the abbot and convent. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 402.

Philip de Gay, son of Robert de Gay and Matilda de Gay, grants to the church and canons of Oseney all his right and claim in the village of Northbroc, likewise of a rent there, viz., two spurs of the value of 6d. or 6d. annually. (c. 1240.) Witn. Genteschin pauper, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 403.
Sale by Sibilla de Saucer of her man Gilbert, the son of Godwin, to the canons of Oseney, for which they gave her 20s. (c. 1160-80.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 1.

Writ of K. Henry II to the archbishops, &c., and to the faithful of all England to this effect, that the abbot and canons of Oseney and all their things and possessions are in his hands and custody and protection, which they shall have and hold freely, quietly, &c. (c. 1160?) Witnessed by Wido, dean of Waltham, at Wodestoc'. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 2.

Henry Deoili grants to Hugh, the abbot, and the canons of Oseney, his man Odulph with his progeny and all his chattels, the abbot and convent giving four pounds and one horse. [Hugh, abbot, 1184-1205.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 3.

John Billuc grants to Dionisia, the daughter of Walter de Oseney, the whole of his land in Oseney, viz. croft, and meadow, and pasture, to hold of Thomas de St. Walery, at an annual rent to the chief lord of 26d., and to him and his heirs 1d. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 4.
Fragment of a decree of Baldwin, archbishop of Canterbury in a tithe ease. (1185-90) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 5a.

Confirmation by Pope Honorius III of a convention, concerning certain tithes, between the abbot and convent of Oseney ("Oxeneia?") and the prioress and convent of Littlemore. Dated at Lateran Id. May, 8th pontifical year, i. e. 1224. [With the bulla.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 5b.

Bond by which Juliana, relict of Hugh Hudd, and Margaret her daughter, undertake to pay to Walter the goldsmith or his assigns xxxiijs., in which case a seld with a solar shall remain to the said Juliana and Margaret as in a certain charter is named, but in default the property to belong to the said Walter. In the event of the payment of the said sum the said Juliana and Margaret undertake not to sell the property to any one but the said Walter. (c. 1240-50.) [See Ch. 478.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 6.

Three (duplicates). Mandate from R[ichard Gravesend], bp. of Lincoln, to the archdeacon of Oxford, not to allow the abbot and convent of Oseney to be disturbed in the possessions which belonged to the church of St. George within the castle of Oxford. Dated 3 Kl. August, 1st of his episcopate. (1259.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 7.

Three (duplicates). Mandate from R[ichard Gravesend], bp. of Lincoln, to R. the archdeacon of Bedford, not to allow the abbot and convent of Oseney to be disturbed in their possessions which belonged to the church of St. George within the castle of Oxford. Dated 3 Kl. Aug., 1st year of his episcopate. (1259.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 8.

Three (duplicates). Mandate of Richard Gravesend, bp. of Lincoln, to the archdeacon of Buckingham, that not to allow the abbot and convent of Oseney to be disturbed in their possessions which belonged to the church of St. George in the castle of Oxford. Dated 3 Kl. Aug. (1259.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 9.

Mandate from R., bp. of Lincoln, to the archdeacon of Buckingham, not to allow the abbot and convent of Oseney to be disturbed in their possessions which belonged to the church of St. George in the castle at Oxford. Dated 3 Kl. August. (1259.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 10.

Interim proceedings in an ecclesiastical cause, in which the abbot and convent of Oseney are plaintiffs and sir William Naton (?), kt., defendant, heard at Lichfield an. 1248 the Wednesday before the feast of St. Leonard. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 11.

Indulgence granted by Galerand, bp. of Beyrout ("Beritensis"), who came to England for alms for the Holy Land. Dated at Oseney 8 Kl. Dec., 9th year of his episcopate. (c. 1245.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 12a.

Decree of the prior of Newport, judge in a cause in which the abbot and convent of Oseney are plaintiffs, and the prior and convent of St. Frideswide and Richard, rector of L..., are defendants. Dated St. Agatha's day, 1245. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 13b.
The will of Nicholas de Weston, proof dated 1261, Thursday before St John the Baptist. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 14a.
The will of Alice de Weston, dated feast of St. Barnabas, 3 Id. June, [22] Ed. I (?). MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 14b

Mutilated charter concerning a suit in which Roger de Amary and Mathew de Bikestrop, executors of John de St. John (?), and the abbot and convent of Oseney are concerned. [Temp. Hen. III.] [1232-1235. See nos. 298-294.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 15.
Confirmation to Oseney by Robert D'Oilly of all their possessions in frankalmoigne. (Copy in 13th century). [Mutilated, written after the death of Robert D'Oilly.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 16.
A list of houses in Oxford held of Oseney in fee. [Mutilated.] (c. 1250) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 17.

Charter (mutilated) by which Geoffrey Dispensarius ... to receive by John, abbot of Oseney, executor of the will of John de St. John, ... 20 ... sterling to the use of Cecilia, daughter of the said John, and quit-claims and indemnifies the said abbot and his executors. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 18.

Certificate by the dean of Tamworth of the due execution of a mandate from the prior of Dunstaple, delegate appointed by the Pope, citing Wakelin, canon of Lichfield, Richard Bagot, Hugh de Aston, and Richard Attemere, to appear in the church of Dunstable before the prior of Dunstable, to answer the abbot and convent of Oseney concerning certain tithes of land and other things. Mandate dated at Houtthon on the vigil of St. Andrew, 1272, and the certificate at Walsale the morrow of St. Lucy, virgin, same year. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 19.

Writ addressed to the sheriff of Oxfordshire by K. Edward [I]., concerning the liberties of the abbot of Oseney, commanding him to allow the same in his bailiwick. Dated at Westminster, 7 ... 2 of his reign. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 20.

An indulgence of 10 days granted by David, archbishop of Cashel to all who should repair to the chapel of St. George within the castle, on St. George's day, and make an offering. Dated at Oseney, 4 Kalends of August, 1277. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 21.

Certificate by the dean of Bedford of his execution of a mandate from the sub-prior of St. Oswald's, Gloucest., to cite the prior and convent of Caldewell ("Caudewell"), citing them to appear before the sub-prior of
St. Oswald's, Gloucester, to answer a complaint of the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at Kerington, 16 Kl. July, 1279.
MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 23a.

Letter of Oliver Sutton, bp. of Lincoln, setting forth the entry in the register of Henry Lexington, bp. of Lincoln, his predecessor, concerning the ordination of vicarages belonging to the abbot and convent of Oseney, within the diocese of Lincoln. Dated at Lidyngton, 5 Id. June, 1284. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 23b.

Writ from K. Ed. [I], addressed to the abbot and convent of Oseney, commanding them to record on their chronicles the oath of fealty of the Scotch barons, in French, taken at Norham the Wedn. after the feast of the ascension, 1291. Dated at Westminster, 9 July, 19 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 24a.

Letter patent from K. Edward I, acknowledging to have received from John de Drokenford for the abbot and convent of Oseney, sub-collectors of the tenths of England, the sum of £90. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 24b.

John ... and Alelmus ... executors of the will of Roger de Nogere, kt., (Nowers ?), acknowledge to have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney the deposit together with the chest in their hands at the time of his death, excepting £100 sequestrated by Matthew de Dunstable for the business of the Crusade (Negotii crucis). Dated 1292, at Oseney, day of St. Edmund K. and M.. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 25.
Giffred de Vezano acknowledges to have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney, collectors of tenths granted to the Pope, the sum of £20. Dated at London, 6 Nov., 1298. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 26a.

An acknowledgment from the abbot and convent of Eynsham that they have received 71s. 8d. from the abbot and convent of Oseney in payment of a certain subsidy. Dated at Eynesham, 8 April, 1301. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 28.

An acquittance by sir Robert de Crevequer, kt., for the payment by the abbot and convent of Oseney for the hundred of North gate, of £10, being part of £20 of annual rent of the King. Dated at Oseney on the morrow of the apostles Simon and Jude, 30 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 29.

An acknowledgment that certain merchants assigned by the pope's mandate, have received of the abbot and convent of Aberconway for the tenths of the diocese of St. Asaph, by the hands of Hugh de Compton, canon of Oseney, the sum of £22 16s. in part payment of the said tenths for the fourth year. Dated at Sutton, 7 Ides April, 1302. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 30a.

An acknowledgment that certain merchants assigned by the pope's mandate, have received by the hands of Hugh de Compton, canon of Oseney, £47 sterling, from the tenths of the diocese of Ban[gor]. Dated at Sutton, 7 Ides of April, 1302. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 30b.

Commission from the prior of St. Peter's, Gloucester, judge delegate in a cause between the abbot and convent of Oseney of one part, and the prior and convent of St. Oswald, Gloucester, and others on the
other part to the prior of Hereford to hear what may be said by the said parties, reserving only the definite sentence. (c. 1260-70) [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 31.

Emma, formerly wife of ... in her widowhood, remits and quit-claims to Ralph de Sutton and Willelma his wife, and the abbot and convent of Oseney, all right in one ... likewise in 10s. annual rent in ... (c. 1280-90?) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 32.
Fragment of an account of a manor belonging to Oseney. [Temp. Ed. I.] (c. 1280-90) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 33.
Fragment of a roll of accounts. Total expenses £218 18s. 7d. Exceeding the receipts by £9 19s. 7 1/2d. (c. 1300) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 34.
Fragment of a roll of accounts, principally payments on account of the abbot, &c. Total of receipts £249 13s. 2d. Total of payments £276 4s. 4 1/2d. (c. 1380-90 (?)) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 35.

Writ from K. Ed. [II]. to the sheriff of Oxford, commanding him to distrain upon the goods of the abbot and convent of Oseney for the non-payment of a rent due to Margaret Queen of England, out of the mills and the Kinges Mede. Dated at Westminster, 6 Feb., 3 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 36a.
Inspeximus charter of King Edward [II], dated ... Aug. 3 of his reign, of grants and donations made to the abbey and convent of Oseney. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 36b.

Mutilated charter by which .... Elfeton, lord of Elfeton, grants to the abbot and convent of Oseney a house. Dated at Oseney the Thursday on the morrow of St. Edward, king, 4 Ed. fil. Edw.. Witn. John de Hampton, mayor, Culferd and Abingdon, bailiffs etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 37.

Memorandum that in the year 1311, and 5 Ed. II, beginning of 4 March, Hugh de Cumpton, canon of Oseney, paid an account before the abbot and seniors, with reference to which account the house of Oseney was bound to him for all debts whether internal or external belonging to the said house, in a sum of £48 and 23 3/4d., and the said Hugh acknowledged himself bound to acquit the said abbot and convent and the said monastery of tenths and procurations against whosoever, whether imposed by the pope or granted to the king by the clergy of the province of Canterbury, unto the day of the above named account. And know that if sir John de Trillawe and other his co-executors shall have apportioned £8 to the abbot and convent for divers debts in which sir Roger de Beaufou was bound to them, and shall have delivered a letter of acquittance to the collectors, then the abbot and convent shall be altogether quit of the payment of the abovesaid £8. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 38.

The abbot and convent of Oseney, collectors of the procurations for the abbot of Lathingiaco (Lagny), and of Sicard de Vauro, nuncios of the pope in England, account (through J., bp. of Lincoln) for three half-pence in each mark of annual value collected from various churches in the archdeaconries of Oxon, Bucks, Bedford, Northampton, and St. Albans. Dated 1312, on the feast of St. Lawrence the martyr. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 39a.
Mutilated acknowledgment by Henry of Canterbury, clerk of the receipt of 5s. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 39b.

An acquittance given by Thomas called 'Le Mareschall,' clerk and scholar, of the University of Oxford, for the payment of five marks by the abbot and convent of Oseney for the first year's pension during the life of the said Thomas. Dated at Oseney the Friday on the feast of St. James, apostle, 9 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 40.

Walter Reynolds, archbishop of Canterbury, acknowledges that in his visitation of the diocese of Lincoln in 1319, having inspected and examined the muniments and privileges of the abbot and convent of Oseney concerning the appropriation of certain churches, and payments of pensions and tithes, he now confirms the same. Dated at Notele, 2 Id. Feb., 1319. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 41.
An acknowledgment that Rigaud de Asser, nuncio of the pope, has received of the abbot and convent of Oseney 7s. for procurations. Dated at London 11 January, 1319. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 42.

An acquittance given by the abbot of Eynsham, collector of the tenths granted by Pope John XXII, to the King, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the payment of 20 li. and 12 pence for the second half of the aforesaid tenth. Dated at Eynsham, 6 (sic, vi) Non. Feb., 1320. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 43.

An acquittance from brothers John de Hengham and T. de Hemenham, to the abbot of Oseney for ... by pope John XXII in the archdeaconries of ... "... idus Decembris," (1320?) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 44.
Fragment of a list of charters and confirmations of properties belonging to the abbot and convent of Oseney, including a charter of Henry IV. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 45.
Fragment of a citation in an ecclesiastical suit before Henry the bp. of Lincoln. (c. 1400) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 46.

An acquittance given by brothers Michael ... to the abbot and convent of St. Mary, Lyra, York diocese, and Walter ... of St. Mary's, Oseney, for 6s. 8d. annual pension. [Partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 47.

A mandate sent by K. Edward III to the abbot of Oseney, that he should deliver to the knights hospitallers the muniments, cups, and ornaments that he holds, and which have been often before demanded of him, belonging to the knights templars lately dissolved. Dated at Worcester, 20 ... 1 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 48.

An acknowledgment given by William de la Marche that he has received of the abbot and convent of Oseney 61s. sterling, for 20 ... sheep which he had ... by the gift of monsigneur le Mortimer, from the sheep of mons. J[ohan?] de Handlo. Dated at London, 4 March, 1 Ed. III. (French) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 49.

Letter of Nicholas, abbot of Eynsham, to the deans of the archdeaconry of Berks, reciting a mandate received from Pope John, dated 3 of his pontificate, to give warning in all churches, in mass on Sundays and holydays, against depriving or defrauding the abbot and convent of Oseney
of any of their rents, lands, houses, books, etc. under pain of excommunication. Dated at Eynesham, 10 Kl. September, 1327. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 50.
Fragment of a copy of an inspeximus and confirmation to Oseney of privileges, &c. Dated 3 Ed. III. [Part of an Inspeximus charter.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 51.

Richard Murimouth, chaplain of the king, transfers at the request of the king to William Murimouth his brother, clerk, an annual pension of 40s., granted to him by the abbot and convent of Oseney, at the instance of the King on the creation of Thomas the present abbot. Dated at Oxford on the feast of St. Luke the "apostle" and evangelist, 1330. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 52.
Restitution of the temporalities of Oseney by K. Edward III, on the election of Thomas de Cudlington to the abbacy of the same. Dated at Staunford, 9 Aug., 4 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 53.

Mandate from Edward, Prince of Wales, to the seneschal of the honour of Wallingford, to release entirely any distraint on the lands of the monastery of Oseney. Dated 5 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] (French) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 54.

An acquittance from Henry of Canterbury to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the sum of 40s. pension, from Michaelmas term, 5 Ed. III. Dated at London, 4 October, 5 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 55.

An acquittance given by the abbot of Eynsham, collector of the tenths imposed by Pope John XXII for 4 years, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the receipt of £20 7s. 5 1/2d. for the second half of the third year. Dated at Eynsham on the vigil of All Saints, 1332. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 56.

An acquittance from Henry of Canterbury, clerk, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the sum of 40s. for pension, for Michaelmas term, 6 Ed. III. Dated at London, 1 Nov., 6 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 57.

An acknowledgment given by the prior of the cathedral church of Norwich, each collector of the tenths imposed for four years, for the receipt from the abbot and convent of Oseney of 16d. for each term of the two last years. Dated at Norwich, 5 Kl. July, 1333. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 58.

An acknowledgment that Richard de Lusteshull, portionary of one portion of the church of St. Lawrence of Romsey, has received of the abbot and convent of Oseney 10s. sterling, due Michaelmas, 1333, for one year's pension, as his portion. Dated at Elygdon, feast of All Saints, 1333. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 59.

An acknowledgment given by the prior of Daventry and John de Wottesdon, rector of Cortenhale, collectors of the 10th imposed for six years, the pope, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the payment of £20 7s. 5 1/2d. from churches, &c. belonging to that abbey. Dated at Daventry, 15 Kl. July, 1336. [The churches are enumerated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 60.

Composition between the abbot and convent of Oseney of the one part, and Matilda, daughter of Reynilde de la Wyk, of the other, concerning her corrody. Dated at Oseney on the vigil of St. Matthew, 1 1 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 61.

An indenture witnessing that sir Richard de Beaufo, kt., John de Croxford, Geoffrey de Astwyk, and Henry atte Grene, collectors of half of the wool in Oxfordshire, according to the act of parliament of 12 [Ed. III], that they have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney four sacks of wool, being the moiety of their shorn wool. Dated at Eton the Monday on the morrow of Palm Sunday, 12 [Ed. III]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 62.

An acknowledgment given by the abbot of Eynsham for the receipt of 13s. sterling from Nicholas, the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at Eynsham on the feast of St. Mary Magdalen, 13 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 63.

An acquittance given by the abbot of Eynsham, collector of the tenths for the king, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for the payment of £39 os. 6 1/2d. Dated at Eynsham on the feast of St. John the Baptist, 1341. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 64.

Writ of exemption granted by K. Ed. III to the abbot of Oseney from attendance at parliament, reciting that he holds the lands of the abbey as of the gift of Robert D'Oilly in frankalmoigne, and not by barony or in capite. Dated 20 Oct, 15 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 65.
The account of William Watford, almoner, from the feast of St. Michael 1342 to the same feast following. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 66.

An acquittance of the prior of St. Bartholomew, London, to the prior and convent of Oseney of ... for the first half of the tenths granted to the king for his expenses "in partibus transmarinis". Dated at London, 7 Kl. of ... 1343. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 67.
Sir Nicholas de Dornford, kt., remits and quit-claims to the abbot and convent of Oseney all his right to an annual pension of 40s. Dated at Otyndon, 22 March, 18 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 68.

Charter of Nicholas de Uppeton, the abbot, and convent of Eynsham, acquitting and indemnifying Thomas, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, for restoring a certain locked chest placed in their custody by William de Staunford, then abbot as he pretended of the said monastery of Eynsham, and others of the monastery. Dated at Eynesham, 6 Non. July, 1345. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 69.
Fragment of the account of John de Bardusle, kitchener of Oseney, from the feast of St. Michael, 21 Ed. III, to the same feast following. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 70.
The will of Martin de Saltford, chaplain, dated 1348, 2 Nov. Oxford. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 71.

The abbot and convent of Oseney, at the visitation of John, bp. of Lincoln, exhibited their records concerning the appropriation of churches, &c. therein named, which the bishop allowed. Dated at Buckeden, 2 Id. Jan., 1350. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 72.

An acquittance given by the abbot of St. James', Northampton, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the sum of 6s. 8d., being the first moiety of the first year of the tenth granted by the king for two years. Dated at Northampton, 5 Kal. May, 1352. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 73.

An acquittance from John de Kellefox, clerk to John, bp. of Lincoln, to the abbey and convent of Oseney, for 48s. 9d, on account of the visitation of the monastery. Dated at Buckeden, 2 Non. Dec., 1357. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 73a .

An acquittance from William Deneby and Richard de Toneworth, proctors of the university of Oxford, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment of 2 marks of silver, of rent by the hands of John de Ibestone, cellarer of the abbey. Dated at Oxford on the feast of St. Nicholas. 1358. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 73b.

An acquittance given by Henry Rooks and William Todeworth, clerk, executors of Thomas Piper, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for money and goods belonging to the said Thomas. Dated at Oseney, 12 October, 1361. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 74.

An acquittance from Simon Lamborne and James Stanton, proctors of the university of Oxford, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment of two marks. Dated on the feast of St. Nicholas, 1361. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 74a .
Fragment of a bailiff's account, 30. Ed. III, of the issues and expenses of some manor or farm. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 74b.

The prior of St. Bartholomew's, Smythfeld, London, collector of the tenths granted to Pope Innocent VI by the clergy of Canterbury, for the diocese of London, acknowledges to have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney, by the hands of Henry Dymnel, 21 1/2d. for their temporalities in the said diocese. Dated at London, 1 Nones August, 1362. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 75a.

An acquittance from Richard Sutton and Walter Wandesford, proctors of the university, to the abbot and convent of Oseney for 26s. 8d. Dated at Oxford the Friday next after the feast of St. Valentine, 1363. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 75b.

William Coc of Whatelee remits to the abbot and convent of Oseney all kinds of actions whether real or personal for any kind of trespass. Dated at Oseney the Saturday next after the feast of the Epiphany, 38 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 76.

An acquittance given to the abbot and convent of Oseney by the dompnus Willelmus [Ha]mon, prior of Coggus for 10s. annual pension. Dated the Sunday next after the feast of St. Michael, 40 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 77.

John de Denton, chaplain, remits and quit-claims his right to an annual pension of 40s. payable by John the abbot and the convent of Oseney. Dated at Oseney, 2 Kl. November, 1317. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 78.

An acknowledgment from Isabella Blaket for the payment of four marks as a corrody from the abbot and convent of Oseney granted to her by the king for her life. Dated at Hanlee in the county of Worcester the Sunday after the feast of St. Mark the evangelist, 44 Ed. III. (French) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 79.

An acquittance given by John de Bures, citizen and draper of London, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the receipt of £17 17s. 2d., by the hands of John Fretewethe, mercer, of Oxford. Dated at London, 10 Oct., 45 Ed. III. (French) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 80.

Peter, the abbot of Abendon, acknowledges to have received of the abbot of Oseney 10s. 3 1/4d. for the second moiety of the tenths of their temporalities and spiritualities in the archdeaconries of Berks and Wilts, granted to the King. Dated at Abendon, 3 Kl. December, 1373. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 81a.

Writ of King Edward III to the sheriff of Staffordshire, announcing the election of John de Bokelond as abbot of Oseney, and commanding a restitution of the temporalities in his bailiwick. Dated .. June, 47 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 265.

An acknowledgment that Henry, the abbot of Peterborough, has received of the abbot, 24 canons, and one brother "convwerso" of Oseney, the sum of 26s., for the subsidy granted to the King by the prelates and clergy of the province of Canterbury. Dated at Peterborough, 15 May, 1377. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 81b.
Fragment of a bailiff's account for an Oxfordshire manor [Cudelynton?]. Temp. Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 82.

Inspeximus and confirmation charter of King Edward II. [Much mutilated.]
MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 83.

Fragment of a manor court roll. Temp. Ed. III. [Illegible.]
MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 84.

An acquittance from Thomas Lyndlowe and John Wendover, proctors of the university of Oxford, for the receipt of 26s. 8d. from the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at Oxford on the feast of St. Nicholas, 1377. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 85.
View of frankpledge of the abbot of Oseney, with a court for the manor of ..., held Nat John the Baptist, 4 Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 86.

An acquittance by Dionisius Faukener to the abbot and convent of Oseney for one robe and 20s., being a certain corrody granted to him by King Edward III for his life, being half a year's payment. Dated at Oseney ... the morrow of the Annunciation of the Virgin, 7 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 87.
An acquittance given to the abbot and convent of Oseney, by Geoffrey, abbot of Eynsham, for ... Dated 7 Ric. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 88.
An acknowledgment that the prioress of Goring has received from the abbot of Oseney 6s. for annual rents. Dated at Garing on St. Katherine's day, 8 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 89.

Charter reciting a bond of the abbot and convent of Oseney in £100 to the prior and convent of St. Frideswide, payable at Michaelmas after the date of this present writing, in case of the non-observance of the covenants and conditions contained in a certain indenture under date of 13 March, 1385. Dated 14 March, 1385, and 9 Richard II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 90.

An acknowledgment by Alice, the prioress of Goring, to have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney an annual rent due at Mich. Dated at Goring, 12 [Oct. ?], 14 Ric. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 91.
An acknowledgment by Lucy, prioress of Goring, to have received of the abbot of Oseney 6s., being part of an annual rent of l0s. Dated at Goring, 22 October, 17 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 94.

Bond given by the abbot and convent of Byttelesdene, co. Bucks, to pay to the abbot and convent of Oseney £53 6s. 8d. at Michaelmas following the date of this bond. Dated 10 July, 15 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 92.

An acquittance given by Stephen Brakkeley and Richard Whelpyngton, proctors of the university, for the payment by the abbot and convent of Oseney of 26s. 8d. Dated on the feast of St. Nicholas, 17 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 95.

Thomas Beckyngham, bachelor of canon law and commissary of John, bishop of Lincoln, by virtue of a commission for visiting the archdeaconries of Oxon and Bucks, certifies the appropriation of certain churches and tithes to the uses of the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at Oxford, 13 Kal. Dec., 1397. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 96.
A fragment. Temp. Rich. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 97.

Writ of K. Henry IV to his escheator of the co. of Gloucester, concerning the election of William Wendovere, canon, as abbot of Oseney, and commanding a restitution of the temporalities in his bailiwick. Dated at Westminster, 16 March, 5 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 98.

Bond in a sum of £17 13s. 4d., given to the abbot and convent of Oseney by John Fyscher and William Goldsmyth of Chinnor, co. Oxon, payable the 1st day of June following the date of these presents. Dated 2 (?) April, 1410, and 11 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 99.

John Drake, clerk, binds himself to the abbot and convent of Oseney in a sum of £100 sterling, payable at Christmas following the date of these presents. Dated on [the morrow of (?)] the feast of St. Luke the evangelist, 13 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 100.
An acquittance of ..., nuncio in England, for 7s. (?) received from the abbot of Oseney. Dated at London, 6 November, ... [Mutilated .] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 101.
Fragment of a roll of accounts, temp. Edw. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 102.
Fragment of an account of rents in Oxford, temp. Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 103.
Fragment of a roll of accounts of payments and expenses, temp. Edw. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 104.
Receipts and payments by John Prinstorpe of the infirmary and hostelry. Dated 1414. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 105.
Fragment of roll of the keeper of the flocks, for the Mich. 2 - Mich. 3 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 106 .
Fragment, with the heading of a bursar's account. "Oseney. Compotus Johannis Westbury, prioris, et Petrus Oxynford, bursar, ab Mich. 11 Hen. VI, ad Mich. 12 ..." MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 107.

Richard Horton of Newbotell in co. Northampton, gentleman, quit-claims to William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, all his right of action, execution, or demand, against the said abbot and convent to the date of these presents. Dated 13 October, 23 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 108.
Mutilated plea relating to differences between the abbot and convent of Oseney and the mayor and bailiffs of Oxford. (c. 1400.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 109.
William, the abbot, and the convent of Oseney, manumit Thomas Hampton, son of Thomas Hampton, senior, their serf, from villenage, &c. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 110
Bond of 20 marks given by John carpenter of King's Sutton to the abbot and convent of Oseney. Temp. Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 111.
Fragment of a roll of accounts (stipends of servants). Temp. Edw. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 112.
Part of the election of Richard Leyceter as abbot of Oseney. Dated the 2nd year of Pope Sixtus IV (1472). MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 113.

Letter to Richard, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, from Thomas, the prior, and convent of Torkesey, Lincoln diocese, notifying the reception of Richard Boston, canon of Oseney, into the said priory of Torkesey, in pursuance of leave given to him. Dated 27 January, 1473. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 114.
Fragment of a roll of accounts, temp. Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 115.

Writ of K. Henry VII to his escheator of the county of Stafford, confirming the election of Robert Oseney, canon, as abbot of Oseney, and commanding the restitution of the temporalities in his bailiwick. Dated at Westminster, 25 November, 1st year of his reign. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 116.

An acquittance from the Exchequer, dated 11 Hen. VII, for the payment of £88 4s. 2 1/2d., less £8 11s. 4d. allowance, by the abbot and convent of Oseney, collectors of the tenths granted by the clergy of Canterbury. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 117.
Memorandum that Richard Hacborn, canon and chamberer of Oseney, received from Symon Erle, receiver of the convent money, 6s. 8d., 1 Oct., 12 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 118.

Exchequer receipt dated Mich. 19 Hen. VII, for £20 due by the abbot and convent of Oseney for the castle mills, King's mede, and for half the fishing of the Thames from Hyde brygge to the castle mills. Sir John Williams, sheriff. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 119.

A petition to the King that he would compel the abbot of Oseney to appear before the council to answer the complaint of Robert Wodecok of Bury St. Edmond's, husbandman, for a debt. Temp. Hen. VII. (English) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 120.

Bond entered into by Robert Wodecok of Bury St. Edmund, co. Suffolk, husbandman, and John Hawkyns of Oxford, glover, in a sum of £20 to the abbot of Oseney, to abide by the award of Harry
Makeney and John Egecombe, arbitrators of all accounts, debts, &c., between John Howse, alias John Catour, and his wife [wife of R. Wodecok] and the abbot of Oseney. Dated 3 August, 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 121.

The abbot and convent of Oseney enter into a bond of £20 to abide by the award of James Souche and Elyas Ruthyn in differences existing between the said abbot and Robert Wodecok, as to the debt due to the latter. Dated 17 July, 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 122.
Quit-claim of Alice, widow of Thomas Skowe, of all actions, demands, &c., to Robert, the abbot, and convent of Oseney. Dated 28 June, 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 123.

Quit-claim by Richard Walys of Oxford, "plommer", to Robert, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, of all actions, quarrels, and demands, to this time. Dated 17 November, 17 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 124.

An acquittance given by William Smith, bp. of Lincoln and chancellor of the university of Oxford, Hugh Hawardyn, and John Matston, [proctors], to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment of 26s. 8d. for an annual pension due to the university. Dated 11 May, 18 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 125.
The account of Edmund Wycumb, keeper of the castle mills, Oxford, and the meadow called Medehey, from Mich. 18 Hen. VI to 19 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 126.

An acquittance from Richard Maiewe, chancellor, John Stokisley and Richard Dudley, proctors of the university of Oxford, for the payment of 26s. 8d. due to the university of Oxford by the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated 9 March, 19 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 127.

Exchequer receipt, dated 20 Hen. VII, for £20 due to the crown by the abbot and convent of Oseney for the castle mills, King's Mede, and half the fishery of the Thames from Hyde brygge to the castle mills. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 128.
Licence from K. Henry VII to the prior and convent of Oseney, giving them authority to elect an abbot in the room of Robert, resigned. Dated at Knoll, 8 Aug., 20 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 129.

Exchequer receipt, dated 25 Jan. 22 Hen. VII, for 109s. 1d. for an account rendered by Hugh Manston, attorney of the said abbot and convent of Oseney, for the profits, &c. from the 14 Nov., 21 Hen. VII, to the 28th of the same month, viz. for 15 days between the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert Osney and the election of William Barton to the abbacy. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 130.

Exchequer receipt for £20 for the fishing and the mills under the castle and a meadow near Oseney called King's mede, &c. to the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated 21 Hen. VII. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 131 .

Exchequer receipt, dated 2 March 22 Hen. VII, for £20 due to the crown by the abbot and convent of Oseney for the castle mills, King's mede, and half the fishery of the Thames from Hide brygge to the castle mills. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 132.
Fragment of an Exchequer receipt for the payment by Oseney of the reserved rent due to the crown for the mills and King's mede. Dated 23 Hen. VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 133.
Fragment of a roll of accounts, temp. Edw. II or III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 134.
Fragment of a roll of farming accounts, [c. 1400 (?)]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 135.
Fragments of a roll of accounts, for plasterers and masons in Oxford. [c. 1460-80 (?)]. [On paper.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 136.
Fragment of a roll of term accounts, temp. Edw. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 137.
Exchequer receipt for £20 for the mills, &c. belonging to the abbey of Oseney, Mich. 3 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 138.

Bond of John Turnour of Oxford, innkeeper, to Robert Tettesworth, in 10 pounds of lawful money to be paid to the said Robert, or his attorney or executors, at Easter next after the date of these presents. Dated 4 April, 8 Henry VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 139.

Letter of the convent of Oseney appointing Thomas Bagot, Thomas Ashley, John Heryng, William Clayton, and others, their attorneys in ecclesiastical suits, &c. Dated 28 April, 1527. [Mutilated] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 140.
An acquittance from the Exchequer for £20, being an annual rent due to the crown from Oseney, for the mills, King's mede, fishery, <c., 19 Henry VII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 141.

Bond given by John Drykusworth and Laurence Evan, wardens of the craft of weavers and fullers, in £20, to abide by the award of John, abbot of Oseney, and William Fryer, alderman of Oxford, arbitrators between them and Godfrey Dyke. Dated 28 (?) Jan., 20 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 142a.

Confirmation of Magna Charta by King Henry III, ordering all castles built or rebuilt since the war with K. John to be destroyed. [1216] Sealed by cardinal Guallo, the delegate (whose seal is lost) and earl William Mareschal, the "rector" of the king and kingdom "quia sigillum nondum habuimus." [With small seal, knight on horseback "S. W. Mareschal".] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 142b.

Confirmation by King Edward I of Magna Charta and the Carta de foresta. Dated at Westminster, 28 March, 28 of his reign. [With seal of a bishop, inscr. broken: "S. ...fratris Joh'is".] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 143b.

OVERTON, Leicester. Memorandum from the official of the bp. of Lincoln, that Thomas de Verdun, rector of Overton, may pay to the abbot and convent of Oseney each year at Michaelmas, according to a composition, the same as his predecessors. Dated at Oxford on St. Andrew's day, 1250. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 234a.

Master Thomas, rector of Overton, by agreement with the abbot and convent of Oseney, and consent of master Robert de Marescal, official of the bp. of Lincoln, obtains the tithes of the abbot and convent at Twicros, viz. 2 parts of the tithes of corn, for a payment of 3s. within the three weeks next after the feast of St. Michael, at Oseney. Dated at Ibstock, St. Laurence's day, 1250. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 234b.

OXFORD (All Saints). Juliana the widow, and Margaret the daughter of Hugh Hudde, grant to Walter the goldsmith, a seld in the Butcherow in All Saints' parish, for which he gave to them 30s. Witness. Peter, son of Torald, then mayor. (c. 1240-50.) ["Macello," endorsement] [See Ch. 6.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 478.

OXFORD (Holywell). Henry, son of Simeon, grants to William the hosier ("hosario") of Oseney, the half of the mill of Haliwell with the appurtenances which the same Henry has in the said mill, to hold in fee at an annual rent of 16s. for all service. For this grant the said William gave one bezant for recognition; and granted to the said Henry the half of the mill he held of the Templars, for his term. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 479.

OXFORD (St. Aldate). Walter, son of Loeca, daughter of Jordan de Eylesburi, grants to the church and canons of Oseney 12d. of annual rent, which he was accustomed annually to receive from a tenement formerly Bartholomew in the parish of St. Aldate's, Oxford. Witnesses. Nicholas de Kyngeston, then mayor of Oxford, Elyas le Quilter and John Cu[lwer]d, then bailiffs, etc. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 480.

Joan, daughter and heir of Robert de Staunton, citizen and fisherman, of Oxford, relict of John Sch... (?), grants to John de Abyndon (?) a tenement in St. Aldate's parish. Dated the Sunday next after the feast of St. Mark the evangelist, 20 Rich. II. Witn. Rich. Garston, mayor, etc. [Much rubbed, and partially illegible.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 481.

Indenture between the abbot and convent of Oseney on the one part, and the master and scholars or fellows of Balliol College of the other, witnesseth that the abbot and convent of Oseney have demised a certain area in Jury lane, Oxon, opposite to the civil law school, standing in length toward the tenement of the master and fellows called ... and abutting on that of John Hamwell, "gentylman", to Balliol College for 99 years, at an annual rent of 3s. 4d. Dated on the feast of St. Gregory the pope, 1443, 22 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 482.

OXFORD (St. Ebbe). Mandate from the official of the bishop of Lincoln, dated Id. Aug. 11th year of the bp. [Groseteste], (Rob. de Mariscis) to Rob de Preston, and Robert, rector of the church of St. John, to hear an appeal from a judgment of the chancellor's court, between the abbot and convent of Oseney and Roger de Lega, a scholar of Oxford, with a mandate addressed by them to the dean of Dorthelestre to cite Roger de Lega to appear before them in the church of St. John. (c. 1245.) Witn. Rob. de Mariscis, dean of Lincoln and archdeacon of Oxford. (d. in or about 1262). MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 485.

Indenture between Thomas, the abbot, and convent of Oseney of the one part, and Thomas Nynehide, principal of Hincksey (Hengsly) hall, situated in Oxford, at the end of a certain lane called Kepeharme lane, in Fish street, of the other part, witnesseth that the abbot and convent have demised to the said Thomas a certain tenement called Grove hall, situated in Pynferthyng strete within the parish of St. Ebbe, in perpetuity, paying annually for the same 9s. Dated at Oseney on the feast of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist, 22 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 486.

OXFORD (St. Edward, All Saints, and St. Mary the Virgin). Quitclaim of Nicholas ... to Ralph ... of a tenement in St. Edward's parish, of a messuage in All Saints', and of one in the parish of St. Mary the virgin. (c. 1300.) Witn. John de Ew, mayor, etc. [Fragment.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 487.

OXFORD (St. Edward). John de Grendon grants to Roger [Mini]kan and Alice his wife, and their heirs, the whole of the tenement in St. Edward's parish, between a tenement of the prior of St. Frid. on the west, and land of the abbot of Oseney on the east, which he had by the will of Agatha de C... Dated at Oxford the Thursday next after the feast of St. John ante port. lat., 6 Ed. [II]. [Mutilated.} MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 488.

William de [St. Edward] and Margaret his wife quit-claim to Henry de Stanford, all their right in one messuage in the parish of St. Edward, between a tenement of the abbot and convent of Eynesham on the one part, and the land of the prior and convent of St. Frideswide on the other. Witnesses. Richard Cary, then mayor, Walter de Farendon and John de Brehull, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated at Oxford, 12 June, 10 Ed. III. [Printed in Cartul. S. Frid. I, p. 151.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 489.

Thomas de Nextebury of Wateretone grants to the abbot and convent of Oseney a cellar with a solar in St. Edward's parish, Oxford, in Little Jawerye, between a tenement of Joseph de Wodestok on the west, and a tenement of Balliol hall on the east. Dated at Oxford the Sunday next after the Epiphany, 22 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 490.

Richard Spragot, Robert atte Wode, John Dolle, William Person, Philip Mercham, Thomas Sherman, Richard Hobcroft, John Pollard, and William Gruflyn, appoint Robert Egebery and Robert Wodehouse their attornies, to receive in their name full possession of a tenement situate in the parish of St. Edward, Oxford, between a tenement of the abbot and convent of Oseney on the south, and a tenement of the warden and scholars of the College of St. Mary Winton, which they have by demise of Rich. Bulkeby, Will. Brygges etc. on the north. Dated at Oxford, 26 March, 32 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 491.

Bond given by the warden and fellows of [New] College to abbot and convent of Oseney for fulfilment of conditions of a lease of a piece of land adjoining Vine hall in Oxford, belonging to the said abbot and convent, for 99 years, at an annual rent of 4s. to New College. [Mutilated.] Dated 6 Aug., 17 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 492.
OXFORD (St. George). Copies of deeds (sales, grants etc.) relating to the foundation of St. George's within the castle. (c. 1200-20?.) [Mutilated fragments.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 493.

Lease granted by the abbot and convent of Oseney to William Bybye, slatter, of their tenement called the Founder's third ("thryd") mansion, in the parish of St. George, Oxford, for 61 years, paying annually 6s. 8d. Dated 3 Feb., 30 Hen. VIII. [Mutilated.] (English) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 494a.

OXFORD (St. John). Agreement made 1 August, 35 Hen. VI,
between John, the abbot, and convent of Oseney of the one part, and Robert, the prior, and convent of St. Frideswide of the other part, of and concerning a wall separating the hall of St. John of the abbey from the hall of the prior and conf. of St. Frideswide, called Bemehall, in the parish of St. John of Merton College. [With seal of St. Frideswide, broken. (A perfect seal in the British Mus. (1150) Sigillum St. Frideswide).] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 494b.

OXFORD (St. Martin). John and Walter de Grendon grant to Stephen de Adington, burgess of Oxford, one seld with a solar in the 'Corvescria' Oxon, between a tenement of John de Abindon on the south, and a tenement which William de Mora holds on the north at an annual rent after the first ten years of 40/. Witnesses. John Docklinton, then mayor, Andrew de Wormenhale and John de Bischopston, then bailiffs of Oxon. Dated at Oxford on the morrow of St. Lucy, virgin, 18 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 495.

Will of Walter de Milton of Oxford containing bequests to St. Martin's church, to Agnes his wife, and mentions John, William, Thomas, Adam, and Eustachius, his sons, and Agnes his daughter. Dated at Oxford the Tuesday next after the feast of the Ascension, 12 Ed. III. (1338) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 496.

John de Brehulle of Oxford quit-claims to John de Bybury all his right in 2s. 8d. annual rent from a certain shop in the parish of St. Martin, between a tenement of John le Smyth, skinner, on the north, and a tenement of the said John de Bybury on the south. Witnesses. Richard Cary, then mayor, John de Norton and John Peggy, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated at Oxford, 8 August, 16 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 498.

Thomas de Wormenhale and Isabelle his wife grant to William de Chinnore, clerk, one shop in the parish of St. Martin, between a tenement of Nicholas Kyng on the one part, and a shop of Henry de Wyghthull on the other. Witnesses. John de Stodle, then mayor, Gilbert atte Wode and Robert Croydon, then bailiffs. Dated at Oxford on the feast of St. Thomas, 31 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 499.

Fragment of a will mentioning Henry Freeman and William Merston, the testator's wife Alice, the churchwardens of the parish, and tenements, &c. in the parish of St. Martin, Oxford. Temp. Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 500.

Convention between Thomas Whitele of Oxford and Isolda his wife, formerly wife of John le Saucer, senior, of the one part, and John Appulford, draper, of the other, relating to dowry from a tenement in St. Martin's parish, near the church. Dated at Oxford, 6 May, 4 Rich. II. Witn. Will. Dagvylle, mayor, etc. Adam de la Ryverc and Walter Wycombe, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 502.

Isabella, relict of Roger Stodle, spicer, of Oxford, formerly daughter to Henry Rolf of Oxford, quitclaims to sir William Northbury, chaplain, and Thomas Wyghtham, all right in a certain messuage and vacant place adjoining, in the parish of St. Martin. Dated at Oxford, 21 Sept., 6 Rich. II. Witn. Rich. Marston, mayor, John ... and Adam de la Ryvede, bailiffs. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 503.

At a court held the Monday next before the feast of St. Alphege, 3 Hen. VI, it was presented that in a tenement in the parish of St.
Martin, Oxon, which was formerly Edward Terschaweis, there are 5 windows constructed within a space of 16 feet, which open on the land of the abbot and convent of Oseney on the east, against the custom. Ordered to be closed within 40 days under a fine of 40s. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 504.

OXFORD (St. Mary Magdalen). Laurence [Kepeherms] (endorsement) grants to William de Kantebrigge certain land without the north gate in the parish of St. Mary Magdalen, viz. that which lies between the land of Ralph Kenne and the land which was Hugh de Bladene's, paying annually for the same 18d. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 505.

John Halegod quit-claims to Ralph de Sualewecleve all right to 2s. annual rent from land in the parish of St. Mary Magdalen. Witness. William de Ibernia, bailiff of Northgate hundred. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 506.

Charter (indented) by which the abbot and convent of Oseney lease to Hugh Blythe of Oxford, a tenement in the parish of St. Mary Magdalen, Oxford, for 20 years, at an annual rent of 13s. Dated at Oseney, 5 April, 22 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 507.

OXFORD (St. Mary the Virgin). Agnes, daughter of Geoffrey, relict of William le Tannur, grants to John Orsin her son, the whole of her land with appurtenances, namely, that which extends from the way called Shidyerdstrete as far as to a lane which is called Gropecuntelane, which land lies between the land which was formerly John de Bridport's and the land of Agatha, relict of Thomas, son of Wyth, in Schidyerde Strete, on the one part, and on the other between the land of Robert de Tobben and the land which was sometime Stephen's the clerk in Gropecuntelane in the parish of St. Mary, Oxford; paying annually for her and her heirs to William le Tannur and his heirs 9d., and to the church of St. Mary 2d., and to herself and heirs 1d. For this donation he gave 100s. Witnesses. Peter, son of Torald, then mayor, Hugh Fane and Adam Cruste, then provosts of Oxford. (c. 1243.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 510.

Alan de Kyleworth of Oxon and Dionisia his wife grant to sir John de Wanere, clerk, parson of the church of Meryton, a certain messuage in Oxford, in the parish of St. Mary the Virgin, in Cattestrete. Dated at Oxford the Saturday next before the feast of St. Thomas the martyr, 10 Ed. III. Witn. Rich. Cary, mayor of Oxford, Walter de Faryndon and John de Brehulle, bailiffs. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 511a.

Adam, son of Juliana de Wyth, grants to the said Juliana his mother, for her life, his tenement in Oxford, in the parish of St. Mary the Virgin, in Shydyerd, between the great school on the north and a tenement of William Spaldyng on the south. Dated at Oxford the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Michael, archangel, 21 Ed. III. [With very singular seal.] (Apparently instruments of some draft "Illud (?) primo med... quicquid agas operis".) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 511b.
Fragment of a charter by which ... quit-claims all right in ... in Cattestrete. [Temp. Ed. II.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 512.

OXFORD (St. Michael's, North). Nicholas Dewy of Oxford
grants to the church and canons of Oseney 2s. annual rent from a seld in the parish of St. Michael at the north gate, which he had by the gift of Iseuda daughter of Roger Mare. Witnesses. Adam Feteplace, then mayor, John de Coleshull and Philip de O., provosts of Oxford. (c. 1267.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 513.

Convention between William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, of the one part, and Robert ..., of the other part, by which the abbot and convent of Oseney have demised to the said Robert one area and in St. Michael's north. (1283.) [Mutilated.] [Counterpart of the following indenture (Ch. 515), much mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 514.

Convention between William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, of the one part, and Robert Blankeneye of the other, namely, the said abbot and convent demise to farm to Robert one area of land and one stable, which lie between the land of the abbot on the north, and the land of Henry Owayn on the south, the land of Richard le Barbur on the west, and the land of the said Robert on the east, in the parish of St. Michael at the north gate, paying annually 3s. Witnesses. Nicholas de Kyngeston, then mayor, Thomas de Sowy and Ralph le Plummer, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated on the morrow of St. Dunstan, 1283. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 515.

Charter by which Geoffrey, son of Robert the smith ("Fabri") of Goldicote, brother and heir of sir John de Goldicote, chaplain, confirms a grant made by another brother to Richard Hunsyngore, clerk, of one messuage in Oxford called Stapeled hall, under the wall of Oxford, made on Sat. next after feast of St. James ... Edw. [II]. Witness. John de Dukelinton, then mayor of Oxford. Dated at Oxford the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Edmund, king and martyr, 10 Ed. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 516.
Enumeration of eight charters in the possession of the abbey of Oseney concerning the tenement of Thomas le Mareschal in St. Michael's parish, north. [c. 1300] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 517.

Hustings court record before Walter Bowne, mayor, Michael Salesbur' and William Dowk, bailiffs of Oxford, the Monday after the feast of St. Matthew the apostle, 22 Rich. II, in which John Hyde acknowledges to be indebted to the abbot and convent of Oseney 6s. arrears of rent from a tenement in St. Michael's north, viz. 6d. a year for 12 years; which tenement formerly belonged to Philip the miller, and in which William Offord now lives. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 518.

Indenture made between the abbot and convent of Oseney of one part, and Thomas Hampton, Alice his wife, and Thomas, son of Simon de Wyght, of the other part, witnesseth, that the abbot and convent demise to the said Thomas, Alice, and Thomas, one shop with a cellar under the shop, with a stone wall towards the tenement of John atte Hyde on the east, situated in the north street of Oxford, in the parish of St. Michael's at the north gate, between a shop of the said abbot and convent on the south, and a shop of the prior of Nonne Eton on the north, and a tenement of John Hyde on the east, for 40 years, paying for the same annually 16s. Dated at Oseney the Friday next after the feast of St. Valentine, 22 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 519.

Indenture by which the abbot and convent of Oseney lease to William
Hetherd a tenement, &c. in the parish of St. Michael's north, [adjoining] the inn called Le Cardinalls Hatt, for ... years at an annual rent of 3s. 4d. Dated ... 1492. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 520.

OXFORD (St. Michael's, South). Alemandina, daughter 'of Geoffrey le Wauter, and Christiana, daughter of the said Alemandina, grant to Alice de Monkenelane the whole of that land which Walter le Corvesor' (shoemaker) sometime had, which land lies between the land of Walter de Farendon and the land of Reginald alderman, weaver, in Southbridge street ("Suthbriggestrate"), in the parish of St. Michael's south, Oxford. (c. 1210-20.) Witn. Pentecost, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 521.

Indenture witnesseth that whereas George Skidmore and Thomas Wymunde of Oxford have granted, and by their charter dated at Oxford, 19 January, 11 Hen. VI, confirmed, to John Mersshfeld of Oxford, one messuage situate in the suburbs of Oxford in the parish of St. Michael's at the south gate, which they had by the concession of John Ypesden of Abyndon and William Swanburne, it is upon the condition of his paying for the same £32 at three several terms. Dated 19 January, [1433] 11 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 522a

OXFORD (St. Mildred). Thomas, son of Robert de Mortune, sells and quit-claims to master Thomas de Bristoll, all his right in that land which belonged to Alice his mother, widow and relict of Robert de Mortune, in Oxford, in the parish of St. Mildred the virgin. Witness. Peter, son of Torald, then mayor of Oxford, and "S' Tome fil' de Mort'". (c. 1232-44.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 522b.

Alice Mymecan grants to Thomas Nextebury of Watureton, one messuage in St. Mildrith's parish, Oxford, near the tenement of the abbot of Oseney on the east part, to hold for the term of her life. Witnesses. Richard Selwode, then mayor, Adam le Longe and John Treulove, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated at Oxford the Thursday on the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 20 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 523.

OXFORD (St. Peter in the East). Simon, son of Henry de Lekamstede, grants and confirms to Randulph de Bruhull two messuages in Oxford, which lie under the walls of Oxford, in the parish of St. Peter in the east, formerly belonging to Henry his father, paying to him 1/2d., to the lords of the fee, viz. William de Chiltun 3s., and to the church of St. Peter in the east 6d., and John, son of Walter, 6d. Witnesses. Adam, son of Walter, and John Cursy, then bailiffs of Oxford. (c. 1241.) See Clarke's Wood, III.9. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525.

William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, grant to Giles de Stockwelle an easement of their wall in St. Peter in the east, for the two only which are conjoint ... their wall which is between Elmehalle and Blakehalle, for which the said Giles and his heirs undertake to pay annually 4d. (c. 1270-80.) [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 524c.

Richard, son of William le Spicer, of Oxford, grants to Nicholas Hosel of Lillingston, and Alice, daughter of the late William de Hedingdon of Oxford, his wife, a messuage in Cattestrete in the parish of St. Peter in the east, between a tenement of John de Schipford on the south, and a tenement of the abbot and convent of Eynesham on the north.
Witnesses. William de Burncestre, then mayor, Richard Cary and Gilbert de Grensted, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated at Oxford the Tuesday next after the feast of the Annunciation B.M.V., 11 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525b.

Nicholas Hosel of Lillingston and Alice his wife grant to John de Wildelond one messuage and a shop annexed in St. Peter in the east, in the street called Cattestret. Witnesses. John de Hampton, then mayor, John Culverd and Stephen de Adyndon, then bailiffs. Dated at Oxford the Sunday on the morrow of St. George, 16 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525c.

John de Wildelond, clerk, grants to John de Bybury one messuage in Oxon in the street called Cattestret in the parish of St. Peter in the east. Witnesses. William de Burcestre, then mayor, Stephen de Adyntone and Symon de Gloucestre, then bailiffs of Oxford. Dated at Oxford the Sunday on the feast of the invention of the Holy Cross, 6 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525d .

Memorandum of the bequest or gift of sir Roger de Marton of three messuages, 16 shops, 2 solars, 1 celar, and 5 acres 3 roods of meadow, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, in the parishes of St. Peter in the east, All Saints, St. Martin, and St. Michael's north, with particulars of the same. (c. 1350). (On paper). MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525f .

OXFORD (St. Thomas). Lefwi Cole grants to Adam the janitor of Oseney, for his service and for 12d., the half of his meadow which lies between Bulestake and the mill of Botley, namely 2 acres and 4 butts, paying annually for the same 3s. For this donation the said Adam gave to him 12d. and to Walter and Matthew his sons 4d. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 525g.
