William, son of Godwin, grants to 'Savore Arzonario' his land in Stocwell, which is between the house of Robert Coc and the house of William Mitterquorne, paying annually to him and his heirs 20d. for all service and exaction, and for this Savore gives him 2s. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 526.

Hugh Tailur grants to Geoffrey the clerk, rector of the church of Acsted (Oxted), that messuage with appurtenances which is between the land of Henry, son of Simon, and the land of Robert Cok, in Stocwellestrete in the suburb of Oxford, paying annually to him and his heirs 2s. For this grant the said Geoffrey gave 40s. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 527.

Roger, son of Baldewin, grants to Robert Cok the whole of that land in Stocwelle which is between the tenement of William the merchant and the house of Savor, which he formerly held of him, paying annually to him and his heirs 20d. For this grant the said Robert gave to him 4s. sterling. (c. 1220-30.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 528.

Geoffrey, rector of the church of Acstede, grants to the church and canons of St. Mary, Oseney, in frankalmoigne, the whole of that land with appurtenances between the land of Henry, son of Henry, son of Simon, and the land of Robert Coc in Stokwellestret, in the suburbs
of Oxford and parish of St. Thomas the martyr, paying annually to the chief lord of the fee 20d. Witnesses. William, rector of the church of St. Benedict, near Cornulle, John Sewy and Hugh Herding, then provosts of Oxford, Jordan their clerk. (c. 1239.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 529.

Roger de Grenham confirms to the church and canons of Oseney the donation which Geoffrey, the rector of the church of Akestede, made to them of land in Stokwelle strete, in the suburb of Oxford and parish of St. Thomas the martyr, paying to him and his heirs 12d. for all service. Witnesses. Peter, son of Torald, then mayor of Oxford, Hugh le Fane (Fanne? Faune?) and Adam Cruste, then provosts. (c. 1243.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 530.

Henry, son of Henry, grants to John, son of Lancelot, his land which lies between the land of John the carpenter and the land of Hugh Cokeny in Stocwellestrete, in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr, in the suburb of Oxford, paying annually to him and his heirs 4s. For this grant the said John gave 20s. sterling. Witnesses. Peter, son of Torald, then mayor, Laurence Ruffus and Robert Mingnot, then provosts of Oxford. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 531.

Peter, son of Turbert the smith, acknowledges that J., the abbot, and convent of Oseney, gave to him and Helen his wife their house in the parish of St. Thomas for their lives, upon condition that they shall not alienate it. Witnesses. Adam Feteplace, then mayor, John de Coleshull and Nicholas de Kingestun, then provosts, (c. 1251-52.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 532.

Juliana, relict of Adam, formerly porter of Oseney, in her widowhood, grants to the church and canons of Oseney the whole of her part of the land which was her husband's in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr, which belongs to her by reason of dower. (c. 1220.) [See Ch. 525b.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 533a.

Walter, son of Agnes Blacsalt, grants to Roger, son of Baldwin of Grennam, the whole of that land and all that belongs to it, lying between Cart street ("viam bige") and the land of John de Ponte in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr, in Stocwellestrate in the suburb of Oxford. [With seal, broken.] (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 533b.

Roger de Grenham, son of Baldewin, binds himself and heirs to the abbot and convent of Oseney, that no rent from tenements of his fee belonging to them in Oxford shall be liable to be sold or alienated from Oseney without the consent of the canons (provided they are willing to give as much as any one else), under a penalty of 20s. Dated on the Epiphany, 1241. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 534.

Convention between Richard, the abbot, and the convent of Oseney, and Robert and Agnes ... , by which the said abbot and convent demise to Richard and Agnes a messuage in St. Thomas' parish. (c. 1255-58.) [Mutilated] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 536.

In the 41st Hen. III, on the feast of St. Laurence, a convention was
made between sir Richard, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, on the one part, and Hugh de Burgo le Mazun and Joan his wife of the other, viz. that the abbot and convent grant to the said Hugh and Joan his wife that messuage with appurtenances in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr, which is between the land of William de Foulewell, le lingedraper, and the land which was sometime Adam's the porter, to hold the same for ever, paying annually 10s. sterling. Witnesses. sir Nicholas de Henred, then sheriff of Oxon, William de Mildecumb, clerk, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 537.

In the 41 Henry III, on the feast of the apostles SS. Peter and Paul, a convention was made between Richard the abbot and convent of Oseney of the one part, and William de Foulewell, le lingedraper, of the other, namely, that the said abbot and convent demise to the said William that messuage with appurtenances in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr, which William de Doddeford formerly lived in, for ever, at an annual rent of l0s. sterling. Witnesses. sir Nicholas de Henred, sheriff of Oxon, William de Mildecumb, clerk, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 538.

Claremunda, relict of Henry Wirle, in her widowhood, quit-claims to the abbot and convent of Oseney and their successors, all right which she has by name of dower in that messuage which Roger de Comenore had by sale of the said Henry her husband, situated in north Oseney, in the suburb of Oxford. For this quit-claim the said abbot and convent gave half a mark of silver. Witnesses. Nicholas de Kyngeston, then mayor, John Culvert and Thomas de Sowi, then bailiffs of Oxford. (1284.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 539.

John, son of Geoffrey the miller ("le Muner"), grants to the church and canons of Oseney, one plot of land in Stocwell stret, which he bought of John ..., which lies between the land of the abbot of Oseney on the one part, and the land formerly John le Carpenter's on the other, paying annually to the chief lords of the fee 4s. and one halfpenny to John Lance. (c. 1250-60.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 540a.

John de Bybury grants to the church of St. Mary of Oseney and Thomas de Cudelynton, the abbot, and canons of the same, in frankalmoigne, a toft and five cottages in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr. Dated at Oxon the Tuesday next after the feast of the Assumption B.V. M., 7 Ed. III. Witn. Rich Cary, mayor of Oxford, Henry de Stonlage and John Bloundel, bailiffs. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 540b.

Thomas, son and heir of Hugh Cockes, lately of Oxford, grants to William Godfrey of Oxford, and Margaret his wife, formerly wife of the said Hugh, his father, one garden lying to the north of the castle of Oxford in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr. Witnesses. Thomas Bayly, mayor of Oxford, Richard Feld and ... Wode, then bailiffs. Dated at Oxford the Sunday next after the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 20 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 541.

An indenture made between master Walter Lyhert , clerk, of one part, and William Godfray of Oxford and Margaret his wife, of the other part, witnesseth that the said Walter demises to William and Margaret a garden lying to the north of the castle of Oxford, in
Irisshemannestrete, in the parish of St. Thomas the martyr and the suburb of Oxford, with a small water course extending from the Thames there to the castle ditch, for their lives, at an annual payment of 4d. Dated 28 July, 22 Henry VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 542.

Indenture made 28 March, 29 King Henry VIII, between Robert King, "bishoppe at Reanentes", the abbot, and convent of Oseney on one part, and William Thomas of Oxford of the other part, witnesseth, that the said abbot and convent lease to the said William all their tenements, orchards, gardens, &c., in St. Thomas' parish, viz. that tenement called the 7th tenement in the Hamel, and many others, for 99 years, paying annually £4 12s. (English) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 544.
Copy of the same lease (Ch. 544) attested by the dean and chapter of Christ Church. 3 Jan. 1598. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 543.

Indenture made between John, the abbot, and the convent of Oseney, of the one part, and William Malherbe of Eynesham and Agnes his wife of the other, witnesseth, that the abbot and convent have demised to the said William and Agnes their manor of Walton, near Oxford, for 21 years, paying annually for the same £6 13s. 4d. Dated at Oseney, 4 Jan., 9 Hen. VI. [Partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 547.

WICK, near Binsey. Reynilda, daughter of Walter de la Wyke, widow, returns into the hands of the abbot and convent of Oseney two of all her tenements which she holds in La Wick, near Beneseye. witn. Will. de Burncestre, mayor of Oxford, Richard Cary and Roger Minikan, bailiff, etc. (c. 1300-10.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 467.

OXPORD. Hugh Kepeherm grants to the canons of Oseney one foot in breadth of his wall of the land of Hugh Salarius, to erect their wall, as much as they wish, so that it be common both to him and them, to put timber on. (c. 1190-1200.) Witn. John teh provost, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 469.

John Kepeherm grants to Elfredus Macecrerus the land near the land which Richard Black (Niger) held towards the south, for 18d. annual rent, and the land which is near the land of Edith, daughter of Osiet, towards the north, for 3s. 2d. annual rent, and one land which is of the fee of William le Keiser, which is between the land of Agnes Noblepas, and the land of Geoffrey, son of Leviva, for 6d. annual rent, to hold the same to him and his heirs, paying at each of the four terms in the year 18d. For which concession he gave to the said John half a mark of silver and 1 lb of pepper. (c. 1200-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 470.

William de Brigia grants to Turald the Cordwainer, his land which Eilwin Hegreford held, which is between the land which was Ralph's, son of Durant, and the ... in fee and heirship, paying
annually 16d. and one pound of pepper for all service. For this concession the said Turald gave one besant for recognition and fealty according to the law of the town of Oxford. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 471.

An acquittance given to Oseney by Walter de la Fenne, clerk, of sir John de Wylyngton, kt., for the payment of 10s., for scutage of the fourth part of one knight's fee in the county of Oxford for the 34 Ed. I. Dated at Oseney, Sund. in vig. of St. Michael, 9 Ed. [II]. Also a copy of a letter of attorney from sir John de Wylyngton, kt., appointing Walter de la Fenne collector for the same. Dated at Wymbervile the Thursday before the feast of St. Matthew, 9 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 472.

Final concord made in the hustings court of Oxford, Monday after feast of St. Botulph 7 Ed. III, before Richard Cary, mayor, and others, by which William Hose of Botley and Katherine his wife acknowledge that the third part of a messuage and 5 shops belong to Thomas le Marshal. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 473.

Fine made at Westminster, .. Richard II, by which Thomas Parage and Joane his wife, in consideration of the payment of one hundred marks of silver, acknowledge the right of the abbot of Oseney and his successors to ... shops in Oxford. [Decayed.] (c. 1390.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 474.
Inquisition (post mortem) taken before the mayor, bailiffs, and others, 33 Hen. VI, on the death of ... [Nearly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 475.

Richard Hacborn, canon of Oseney, and receiver of the rents of the town of Oxford, acknowledges to have received of David Dier, bruer of Oxford, 8s. for a house in which a certain John Power now lives. Dated 29 November, 1494. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 476.

Thomas Key, clerk, one of the executors of the will of James Souche, has received of the abbot and convent of Oseney 54s. for a certain annual quit-rent going out of certain lands and tenements called 'Bassett's fee' alias 'Bulk ley's rents' for one year and a half ending the feast of the Annunciation B.V.M. last past. Dated 8 May, 19 Hen. VII. (1504.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 477.

Fragment of a rent roll indorsed by A. Wood 'circa 1257,' containing' rents in the following parishes: St. Aldate's, St. Michael's south, St. Cross, St. Giles', St. Mary Magdalen, St. Peter's in the east, St. John, and St. Edward, within the city of Oxford. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 548.
Fragment of a rent roll for the city of Oxford, containing the parishes of St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin's, and St. Peter le Bailey. (c. 1300.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 549.
Fragment of a roll of receipts from property in the city of Oxford, temp. Edw. III or Rich. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 550.
Mutilated rent roll, temp. Hen. IV (c. 1380-90), for the parish of St. George. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 551.
Fragment of a rent roll for the city of Oxford. (c. 1380-90) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 552.

Fragment of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, containing rents in the following parishes, St. Ebbe's, St. Aldate's, and St. Michael's south, St. Giles', St. Mary Magdalen. [Temp. Hen. IV. (c. 1400)] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 553.
Fragment of a rent roll, All Saints' parish only. (c. 1400.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 554.
Fragment of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, St. George's parish only. [Temp. Hen. IV or VI.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 555.

Heading of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, containing the name of Edmund Wycumbe, collector of the rents, and the following note: 'Anno Regni Regis Henr vj. xiij. Isto anno facere fuere plures edificaciones nove ut potest in. paroch. Sancte Marie Virgis et Sancti. Georgii.' MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 556.
Part of a roll of payments for property within the city of Oxford. Expenses of repairs, or houses, servants' wages, etc. (c. 1400.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 557.
Fragment of a [rent] roll of receipts for property in Oxford. [Temp. Edw. III ?] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 558.
Fragment of a roll of accounts, temp. Hen. VI. Expenses for houses, &c. in Oxford. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 559.
Fragment of a roll of expenses in Oxford. (1380-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 560.
Expenses on houses in St. Mildred's parish, &c. (1380-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 561.
Fragment of a rent roll and payments for houses in the city of Oxford. (c. 1380-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 562.
Fragment of a roll of rents in Oxford. The parishes of St. Mary Magdalen and St. George only. (c. 1380-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 563.
Fragment of a roll of receipts from tenements, &c. in the parishes of St. Michael's south, and St. Giles', St. Mary Magdalen, and St. George. [Temp. Hen. VI.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 564a.

OSENEY (North). An amended agreement between Richard, the abbot, and convent of Thame, and the abbot and convent of Oseney, by which they covenant to pay 36s. and 8d. to Oseney in recompense for the small tithes of North Oseney, upon which [Rewley] abbey, of the foundation of Edmund, Earl of Cornwall, had been nearby built, until 1/2 a mark of annual rent shall be restored to Oseney from a piece of land near the chapel of Frees, which Walter de Crocford held of the said canons, and 30s. of rent be provided from some other source. Dated at Thame on the day of the Assumption B.V.M., 1281. [With fragment of small seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 564b.
PUSEY, co. Berks. H[ubert], bishop of Salisbury, confirms to the canons of Oseney the church of Pesi with its appurtenances. (1188-93.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 147.
Ralph de Chaisneto grants to the church and canons of St. Mary, Oseney, two hides of land in Pesi. (c. 1200-10.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 148.

Chirograph of W[illiam], bp. of Salisbury, concerning the temporary payment of an annual pension of ten marks to Robert, the treasurer of Salisbury, by the abbey and convent of Oseney, patrons of the church of Peseia, Salisbury diocese which had been granted to Marinus, formerly ... of the Pope. Dated at Salisbury on the feast of St. Michael, 1252. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 149.

PUSEY, ARDINGTON, HARWELL, LEDCOMB, and ELSTON. Confirmation by Robert, the bishop of Salisbury, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, of an annual pension of 4 marks from the goods of the church of Peseya by the hands of the vicar for the time being, likewise 2 parts of the tithes of the lordship of Ardyngton, and 2 parts of all things titheable in the lordships of Harewell and Ledecombe, and the tithes of 3 hides and the mill of Elstone. Dated in the monastery of Abendon, 12 Dec., 1432. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 150.

RADCLIVE, co. Bucks. Composition between master Walter, rector of Radclive, and the abbot and convent of Oseney, concerning two parts of the small tithes of the church of Radclive. Dated 1251. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 184.

RISINDON (Little), co. Gloucester. Memorandum that in the year 1278, on the vigil of St. Laurence, a convention was made between the abbot and convent of Oseney on the one part, and master Roger de Sowy on the other, viz. that the said master Roger grants and quitclaims for himself, his heirs and assigns, all right in the patronage or advowson of the church in the manor of Little Rysindon, provided that the abbot and convent shall present to the same church any priest or other of fit and good life, who may be willing and able annually to perform priestly functions, under a penalty of deprivation of the benefice. And that they accept security from the person presented to the same, of observing the underwritten articles, at the time they bind him for payment of the pension due to them, namely, that in each week he shall celebrate one mass for the lord of the manor in the said church, provided that the solemn feasts do not hinder, and in mass and one collect daily pray for the souls of William and Sarah, the parents of the said Roger, and also their anniversary mass shall be solemnly celebrated in the same church. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 223.
ROUSHAM, co. Oxon. Fragment of a charter containing the names of Roger Foleiot and Bartholomew Foleit and Fulk Basset as witnesses among them. (c. 1160-70?) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 404.

Robert Foliot of Rolesham and William Foliot his heir, grant to Walter Bervelie for his homage and service, one messuage in the village of Rolesham, viz. that which Richard Grent held, and 9 acres of their demesne in one field, and 9 acres in another, to hold to the said Walter and Alice his wife and their heirs. And after the decease of the said Walter, they grant to his wife Alice another 9 acres in one field, and 9 acres in another, so that she has 18 acres in each, paying annually one pound of cummin. Also they grant common of pasture for cattle that feed within their lordship. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 405.

Grant from Robert Foliot, with the consent of William his son, to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, (especially for the soul of Philip de Noville) the whole of his land with a curtilage which Hawise, wife of Milo, held in Rodolvesham. (c. 1200-10.) Witn. "Absalon cognato meo" etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 406.

S[imon] and W., abbots of Thame and Bruern, and N[icholas], prior of Eynesham, by authority of a letter of Pope Innocent III, dated the Monday next after the feast of St. Gregory, in the year of our Lord 1216, determine
a cause concerning two parts of the tithe of 7 1/2 acres of the lordship of Thomas de St. Walery in Rovelesham between the abbot and canons of Oseney against Ingeram, rector of a moiety of the church of Rovelesham. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 407.

Mandate from the court of Arches to the dean of Woodstock, concerning a suit between the abbot and convent of Oseney, and Peter, who appears for the rector of Rollesham. [Temp. Ed. II (?).] [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 409.
ROUSHAM and DUNSTEW. Decree relating to Rousham church and Dunstew. [Mutilated and illegible.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 410.

ROUSHAM and BARTON. Richard Folioth of Rolesham confirms to the church and canons of St. Mary, Oseney, the donation and concession which Henry de Sandon, clerk, made to them by his charter of the whole of the land which he held of the fee of the said Richard in Barthon and in Rolesham, paying annually for the land of Barthon 4d., and for scutage 18d., and for the land of Rolesham one pound of cummin. For this grant the said canons gave 4 1/2 marks of silver. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 408.

SANDFORD, co. Oxon. Thomas, son of Maurice de Sandford, with the assent of Alice his wife, grants to William Atenassche of Nethorton, and Ysolda, daughter of the said Thomas, and her heirs, two cottages in the village of Sandford, namely, situated between the cottage of Ysolda le Webbe on the one side and a cottage of .... le Welssche on the other, with a curtilage adjacent, and 2 acres of land in the field of the same village, whereof one acre lies in the north field in a culture which is called 'Le Dene,' between the land of Joan le Kyngkes and the land of Ralph Chapeleyn, and one acre lies in the south field in a culture which is called 'le Morforlong,' between the land of ... Lordyng on the south part; also he grants to Ysolda his daughter one middle selion of land in the croft held by Ysolda le Webbe for the term of her life. Dated at Sandford on the day of St. Margaret the virgin, 4 Ed. [II]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 411.

John de Shareshull grants to William atte Asshe of Nethereorton, two acres of arable land in Sandford, paying annually for the same 1 d. Dated ... on the feast of St. Michael of the mount ("in Monte Tumba"), 8 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 412.

Convention by which the abbot and convent of Oseney grant to Robert de Berewyk, for his life, a certain messuage with a curtilage in Sandford. Dated 19 [Ed. III]. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 414.

William de Shareshull recites that Walter, vicar of Sandford, held the mill of Sandford for a term of 20 years, at a rent of six marks, and that he now grants the same to Roger de Cottesford and Catherine his wife. Dated ... St. Augustine, apostle of Angles ("Anglonum episcopi"), .. Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 415.

Indenture witnessing that the abbot and convent of Oseney have
demised to Henry Colles of Sandford, and Juliana his wife, and Thomas and Richard their sons, one plot and 2 virgates and one acre of land with a certain pasture and a water-mill and the meadow near the mill in the village and fields of Sandford, for 60 years, at an annual rent of 53s. 4d. Dated at Oseney on the Purification of the B. Virgin, 34 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 416.

Indenture witnessing that John Haseley, canon and seneschal of Oseney, demises in the name of the abbot and convent to Richard Whiteof Radeford and Alice his wife, one plot, two virgates, and one acre of land, and a certain pasture and water-mill and field near the mill, in the village and fields of Sandford, for 40 years, paying annually 53s. 4d. Dated at Oseney, 4 October, . . Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 417.

SANDFORD and LEDWELL. Licence from K. Ed. [II] to John de St. John of Lageham, to enable him to enfeoff John de Wilton, in two messuages and five virgates of land situated in Sandford and Ledwell. Dated at York, 6 Feb., 12 of his reign. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 413.

SHENSTON, co. Stafford. Charter of Robert de Oiley to Albinus, priest of Schenestan, Roger, son of Alarus, Ralph de Berra, and their honest men of Schenestan, setting forth that, with the counsel and consent of Fulk his brother, and consent of his sons Henry and Gilbert, he has granted to Hugh de Tiwia his land of Stanhale which is a member of his manor of Schenestan. (c. 1120-30.) Witn. Walter, archdeacon, Walchelin Waard, Mabun etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 246a.

SHENSTON, co. Stafford (?)Hugh de Tiwa, with the counsel and consent of his wife, grants to the church of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, his land ... and all that belongs to it; also Robert D'Oilly his lord, from whom he holds, grants and confirms this gift, with the consent of his wife and his son Henry. (c. 1130-40.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 247.

Composition between the churches of Lichesfeld and Oseney, made concerning the church of Senestan, namely, that the church of Oseney pays annually to Lichesfeld 7s. so long as H. de Brai, clerk, shall hold the same, and after his death 10s. This composition made in the synod celebrated at Lichesfeld after the octave of Pentecost next after the consecration of Robert, bp. of Worcester. (June, 1191.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 248.

Letter of Walter de Tiwa to the king's justices reciting the gift of Stanhale, part of the manor of Shenston, by Robert de Oilli to Hugh de Tiwa, his great grandfather, for his service, and by the said Hugh to the abbey of Oseney, before any of tbe ancestors of William de Brai had anything in the manor of Shenston, and praying that the said canons and their men shall not be unjustly disturbed, but that the gift of his ancestors may be safe and remain to the said canons without vexation. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 249.

Final concord, made at Oxford on the vigil of St. Martin, 5 John, between Hugh, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, querents, and William Ruffus of Waleshal, deforciant, concerning common of pasture of the whole of the wood and land of the same William which is between Stanhale and Sulfhill, by which the said William acknowledges the said
wood and land to be the right of the said abbot and convent, to hold the same in frankalmoigne, and they receive the said William to the benefits and prayers of their house of Oseney. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 250.

Geoffrey, bp. of Coventry, confirm abbot and convent of Oseney the appropriation of the church of Shenston, which they had obtained by the concession of William de Brai, patron of the said church, and the concession and confirmation of H., predecessor of the said Geoffrey. (c. 1200.) Geoffrey, bishop of Coventry, 1198-1208. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 251.
Fragment of a grant from Robert de Gr[endon] to Andrew, son of William de Stanhale ... (c. 1220-30.) [Endorsed] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 252.

William de Waleshal grants to the abbot and convent of St. Mary, Oseney, and to their men of Stanhale, in frankalmoigne, common of pasture for all their cattle in Cleyhunger, with all the privileges which they have in his wood of Solfhull, as in the chirograph made in the King's court (Ch. 250). (c. 1204.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 253.

Sir Robert de Grendon, kt., quit-claims to William de Wythull and Alan de Sutton, clerk, that plot of land with the oak, containing 5 ft. in breadth and 100 ft. in length, which lies between the croft of William the forester, and the drove which leads from the village of Fulverdel to the village of Little Stonhale. (c. 1220-30.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 255.

Sir John de Grendon, kt., grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, five royal acres of land (acras terre regales), viz. 4 acres together in Hok to the east of the village of Little Stanhale, between his culture which is called Hok and Little Stanhale, and one acre between the land of William Abl:o, and Blakelee. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 254.

William, son of Drogo de Alrewych, grants to Oseney and all their men of Stonhale, free common of pasture for all their cattle throughout the whole of his land of Alrewch. (c. 1260-70.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 256.

Letter of Robert, archbp. of Canterbury, to the bishop of Lichfield ordering enquiery, concerning the appropriation of the church of Shenstone to the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at ...., 1276. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 257.

Copies of 3 charters, viz.: 1. William, son of Drogo de Alrewich, grants to the church of St. Mary, Oseney, and to their men of Stanhale, common of pasture in the whole of his land at Alrewich. (See Ch. 256.) 2. William Ruffus of Waleshale grants to Oseney common of pasture of his lands between Lichfield and Dudley. 3. Robert de Barra grants to Oseney common of pasture over the whole of his land of Barra and of Alrewich. (c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 258.
Richard le Rose of Schenestan grants to Ralph de Grendon his messuage that he holds in the village of Thornes. (c. 1290-1300.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 259.

Charter (indented) reciting that in the time of war, and in consequence of barrenness, a controversy was moved concerning the augmentation of the vicarage of Scenstan before Robert, archbishop of Canterbury, and his commissary, between Adam, perpetual vicar of the said church, of the one part, and the abbey of Oseney, appropriators of the same, of the other, which was amicably settled thus: the said abbey grants "la gratia" to him in his life while vicar the tithes of the mill of
Shenston, with two quarters of mixed corn and one quarter of oats, at the feast of St. Michael, and so much likewise of corn between the feast of the Purification and the Annunciation B.V.M., and about the Gules of August, one cartload of hay and two cartloads' of straw or forage for one horse, to be carried from their manor of Mosbarne by the hands or delivery of their bailiff for the time being: and this to become no precedent hereafter. Dated at Oseney the Ides of July, 1296. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 260.

Letter from Walter, bishop of Lichfield and Coventry, acknowledging a voluntary gift for 60s. of the church of Schenestan by Roger Marischal canon of Lichfield and renouncing for himself and his successors any right to claim in consequence any like payment from the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated at Eccleshal, 3 Non. July, 1319. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 261.

An acquittance from the dean and chapter of Lichfield for 16s. 8d., paid by Oseney for their church of Shenston, for the tenth granted by Pope John XXII to the King for the defence of the kingdom. Dated the Friday next after the feast of St. Matthias, 1322. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 263.
An acquittance given to Oseney by the abbot and convent of Burton, sub-collectors of the 10ths, for 6s. due from the church of Shenston. Dated Kl. June, 1330. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 262.

An acquittance given by the abbot and convent of Burton, subcollectors of the tenths imposed by Pope John XXII, for the archdeaconries of Stafford, Salop, Chester, and Derby, to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment of 16s. 8d. for their church of Shenston. Dated at Burton the Thursday before the feast of St. Martin, 1330. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 266.

John de Depynge, canon of Lichfield, and Roger de Denford, vicar in the same, collectors of the procurations of the papal nuncios, the cardinals Peter and Bertrard, acknowledge to have received of the abbot and convent of Oseney for Shenston 8s. 4d., and for temporalities in the archdeaconry of Stafford 3s. 3d. Dated at Lichfield the Wednesday next after the feast of the beheading of St. John Bapt., 1340. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 264.

Indenture whereby Thomas, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, lease to Gilbert de Teddesleye and Felicia his wife, and their sons John and Thomas, for their leases, that forge and messuage which William de Sardone held at their will in Thornes and Stonhale, paying annually 8d. sterling. Dated at Oseney on the feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 14 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 267.

Power of attorney from John, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, to John Strattone and Robert Swyn[sen] to be their proctors at the visitations, &c. of the bishop of Lichfield or his commissary. Dated at Oseney, 27 May, 1390. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 268.

An acquittance given by the abbot of Hulton to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment by them of l0s. for the tenth granted to the King. Dated at Hulton, Sunday after the feast of Sts. Philip and James, 6 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 269.

SIBFORD GOWER. Felicia, daughter of Brian de Sibbeford, grants to the church of St. Mary, Oseney, and the canons there, in frankalmoigne, the gift and concession which John, son of Brian, her
brother, made to them of 5 virgates of land in Sibford of his demesne, with the head court and all that he possesses there. (c. 1240-50) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 417a .

Letter of sir John Lovell, kt., to the seneschal, bailiffs, and guardians of his fee, certifying that he has received homage of J., abbot of Oseney, for the tenements he holds in the village of Sibford Gower, co. Oxford, and therefore he is not to be disturbed or to be taken. Dated at Oxford the Monday next after the feast of St. Matthew, evang., 48 Ed. III. (French) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 417b .

STOKE (South), Oxon. Thomas de Stokes grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, one half acre of arable land in the field of Stokes, which lies near the grove of the said canons at Appelhanger, and extends in length from east to west. Witn. Geoffrey Marmion, William Marmion his brother, etc. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 417c .

STONE, co. Bucks. William de Clovill grants to the church of St. John the Baptist of ..., in frankalmoigne, for the health of his soul and Matilda his wife, two acres of land, viz. one acre which lies between Chilcumbe and Mauling, and one other in another field. (c. 1160-70.) [Endorsed as "Stanes".] [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 185.

William de Braci, with the consent of his wife and Gilbert his heir, grants to Wygod, the prior, and the canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, the church of Stone, one hide of land, and all that appertains to it. [Wygod, 1138-68.] (Copy made late in te 13th century.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 186.

Martin de la Grene, for the health of his soul, &c., grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, one acre of land in Stanes, viz. 1/2 an acre in the north field and 1/2 an acre in a culture called 'Cuseloweforlong'. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 187a.

Sentence of master Arlotus, nuncio of the Pope in England, concerning an alleged vacancy in the church of Stanes belonging to the abbot and convent of Oseney, confirming the abbey in it, collation to which does not belong to the Pope by lapse Dated 2 Aug., 1258 at London in the house of the bishop of Salisbury. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 188.
Fragment of a deed relating to the preceding case attested by the same notary (as Ch. 188), Thomas de St. German. (1258) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 189.

Roger de Bracy, lord of Stone, Richard de St. Clare, William de Bracy, William de la Mersse, William Blackstan, John, son of Fulk, Walter de la Mersse, Gilbert le Gode, William de Suthcote, John, son of Martin, Geoffrey de St. Clare, Robert West, John, son of Hugh de Bissopeston, William de Temple of Bissopeston, William le Fraunceys, Jordan his brother, Roger de Castre, with the unanimous assent of themselves and their men of Stone, grant and quit-claim to the abbot and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, all right which they have in common in that rode of land which they had in exchange from Richard de St. Clare lying near their sheepfold, together with a selion of land upon which was antiently placed their sheepfold. (c. 1290.) [4 seals, the rest lost.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 187b.
The testimony of six witnesses concerning the title of Oseney to the church of Stone. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 191.

Robert de Bracy confirms to the abbot and convent of Oseney lands &c. in Stone which they have of the fee of sir William de Roos, knight. (c. 1314.) [Mutilated.] Same witnesses as to the next deed (Ch. 193). MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 192.

Robert de Bracy, son and heir of Roger de Bracy of Stone, confirms to the church and canons of Oseney all donations and concessions which his ancestors made to them, viz. in the fields of Stone one ... and the advowson of the church of Stone with all tithes, &c. Dated 7 Ed. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 193.

Final concord, dated at Weston, 12 Hen. IV, between William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, of one part, and John Pygot and Marian his wife, and Robert May and Ellen his wife, of the other part, concerning one messuage and two carucates of land, and 24 acres of meadow in Stone, by which the right of the abbot and convent to the same is recognised by the said parties, they receiving 100 marks of silver. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 197a.

An indenture between Richard, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, of the one part, and William Venour of Donyngton, co. Bucks, and Richard Venour his son, of the other part, being a lease of the rectory of Stone, near Aylesbury, for 24 years at an annual rent of £20. Dated at Oseney on St. Mark's day, 1474. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 198.

STONE and HARTWELL. Richard Pykot de la Forde and Hugh atte Temple de la Mershe grant to John Bracy of Stone and Alina his wife the half of their lands, rents, tenements, &c., in the parishes of Stone and Hertwell, which they inherited from Robert Sencler, senior. Dated at Stone the Friday on the feast of the Holy Innocents, 49 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 194.

An indenture by which John Bracy of Stone and Alina his wife enfeoffs William, vicar of Kidlington, Eli, vicar of Wycomb, Ralph Hales, and John Worton, with certain lands in Stone and Hertwell which were Robert Sender's, sen., and after his death descended by heirship to Richard Pykot de la Forde and Hugh atte Temple de la Merssh. Dated at Stone on the feast of St. Matthew, evang., 11 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 195.

John Bryan, citizen of London, and John his son, recite that whereas William, vicar of Cudlington, Ralph Hale, and John Worton, hold one toft 8 acres of land in Stone and Hertwell in demesne as of fee, and John Bracy and Alina his wife hold for their life one messuage one carucate of land and 12 acres of meadow in the same villages, the reversion belonging to the said William, Ralph, and John, which said lands, &c. are held of the said John and John by an annual payment of 9s., by this charter they grant license to the said William, Ralph, and John to enable them to assign the said lands to the abbot and convent of Oseney. Dated 10 February, 13 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 196.

STONE and KIMBELL (Great). Composition (indented) between John, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, and Robert, the abbot, and convent of Missenden, being an exchange of the tithes of Stone and Great Kymbell. Dated 10 July, 1459. [Fragment of seal of Missenden abbey.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 197b.

STOW, co. Gloucester. Henry, son of Lewis, grants to Simon ... acres of arable land lying in the field called ... of Stow, ... paying annually to him and his heirs eight pence, and giving now 16s. 8d. (c. 1240-50.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 199a.

Robert le Bel of Stowe grants to Robert le Bel his son and heir one virgate of land in ..., which Robert de Toreny gave to him, for his homage and service, at an annual rent of one pound of cummin, and an acquittance from all regal service. Witness. Thomas, abbot of Winchcombe. (c. 1230.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 199b.

Oliver, bp. of Lincoln, to master John le Fleming, Josceline de Kirningston, and Walter de Wutton, canons of Lincoln, appointing them judges in all causes and actions [concerning the patronage of the church of Stowe?]. Dated 2 Kl. May, 1291, at Stowe Park. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 200.

An obligation, indented, between the abbot and convent of Oseney and the abbot and convent of Bittlesden, that they will abide by the award of the abbot of Westminster and the dean of Oxford concerning tithes in Dodford belonging to the church of Stow. Dated 12 July, 15 Ric. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 203.

STOW and BIBURY, co. Glouo. A fragment of an episcopal confirmation to the abbey of Oseney of the churches of Stow and Bibury, formerly belonging to the church of St. George. Dated Sept. 14. Temp. Hen. IV or V. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 202.

SWERFORD. Walter de Stowe, parson of Swerford, grants to sir .... Shareshull, kt., one messuage and one virgate of land in ... of which he and others now deceased had been enfeoffed. Dated at .... St. Thomas the martyr, ... Edw. [III?]. [A fragment.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 418a.

Memorandum of an agreement made on the morrow of St. Clement, 1259, between the abbot and convent of Oseney and sir Reginald, son of Peter, by which they mutually bind themselves to remit all actions moved between them in the King's court with the exception of a question concerning the mills of Swereford, with liberty to the abbey to collect the tithes freely; in return, Reginald and his wife Alice are received to the benefit of prayers. Dated St. Andrew's day. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 418b.

TEW (Little), co. Oxon. Alan ad Fontem of Stepulaston, son of Ralph de Stepulaston, grants to Robert atte Lake of Great Tywa and Christiana his wife that messuage with a curtilage and 16 acres of arable land, and one acre, one rood of meadow, in the village and fields of Little Tywa, which the said Alan had by demise of Ralph his father, paying annually for the same 2d. For this grant the said Robert and Christiana gave five marks of silver. (c. 1300.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 418c

Robert de Leburne grants and confirms the donation which Alan, son of Geoffrey, made to Robert, son of Geoffrey, his brother, of land in Little Tywa of his fee [la Burne's]. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 419b.

Robert, son of Geoffrey, grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, the whole of his land in Little Tiwa which he bought of Alan, son of Geoffrey, his brother, for 40 marks of silver, viz. 3 hides
with the whole lordship and service of half a hide which Ralph, son of Henry, held. Witn. Robert de Amauri, William de Bruges, etc. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 420.

Fine made at Westminster, Michaelmas, 13 K. John, between Gilbert de Hida, plaintiff, and Clement, the abbot of Oseney, defendant, concerning six virgates of land and one messuage in Little Tywa, by which the said Gilbert remits and quit-claims for himself and heirs to the church of Oseney all right in the same. And also he remits for himself and heirs all his right in 8 virgates with appurtenances in the same village, namely that which Robert de Nevill his uncle gave to the said church, in frankalmoigne. For this remission the said abbot gave 10 marks of silver. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 421.

Ellen, daughter of Ralph de Stepelaston, in her widowhood, sells to Alan ad Fontem, her brother, for 40s. of silver, all her right in a messuage with a curtilage in the village of Little Tywia near the messuage of Richard de Alarsworthe; also all her right in the lands and tenements which Beatrice her sister held in the same village. Witn. the same as the following deed (Ch. 423), although written by very different hands. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 422.

Helen, daughter of Ralph de Stepuleston, in her widowhood, grants to Robert, son of Alan ad Fonten of Stepuleston, for 40s., a certain house, formerly a solar, with a curtilage opposite, in Little Tiwa, near the messuage of Richard de Aldeswrthe, which Ralph her father gave her in marriage dowry, saving to her the whole of the arable land with the field adjoining the said tenement; rendering annually one sunflower. (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 423.

Richard, the vicar of Ministre, and Alice de Sydintone, his sister, quit-claim to William, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, all their right in one virgate of land, with a messuage, fields, and other appurtenances in Little Tywa, in which they claim to have right by a sale which John de Stoke and Alice his wife made to them of the said virgate, &c., because the said John and Alice were not able to infeoff them. (2 Edw. I) Witn. Gilbert de Kyrkeby, sheriff of Oxon., etc. (c. 1274.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 424.

Richard, the vicar of Ministr', and Alice de Sydinton, his sister, quit-claim to John de Stokes and Alice his wife, their right in the virgate of land, with a messuage and appurtenances in Little Tywa, bought of the said John and Alice, but which they were unable to warrant; upon having their money refunded. Witness. Gilbert de Kyrkeby, then sheriff of Oxford. (c. 1270.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 425.

Robert de Broc of Little Tywa grants to John Long (dicto longo), of the same village, one messuage and one virgate of land, formerly held by Gilbert le Mason, paying annually at Easter one halfpenny. For this grant he gave 9s. sterling. [Robert, son of Robert de Broc and Richard de Saunford] (The names are filled up from deeds which are copied in the Oseney Chartulary). (c. 1280-90.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 426.
Grant from ... for 20s. to lady Katherine Love in Little Tywe, which Richard de Saunford held of the said Robert [paying annually] five pence. (c. 1250-60). [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 427.

Robert, son and heir of Robert de Brok, grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, that messuage and croft which Alice, relict of William de Pateshull, held of him in Little Tywa; also
he gives to the said church the said Alice formerly his serf and Roger, Robert, and Alice, children of the said Alice, and all that belongs to them. Witn. Robert de Kyngeton, bailiff of Wodestok, etc. (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 428a.

Convention dated the Saturday next before the feast of St. Barnabas, 16 Ed. [I], between Roger, abbot of Oseney, and the prior of Coges, and John de Broke, lord of Little Tyw, and others, the free tenants of the said village, of the one part, and John de Pratell, lord of Great Tywe, and Stephen de Pratell, and John, at that time servant of the parson of the same, concerning the right of common of pasture in cultures called Costow and Wodeweye. Witn. Robert le Eyr, bailiff of Wodestoke, etc. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 431.
Writ from K. Ed. II to the sheriff of Oxford, concerning the inclosure of waste lands at Little Tywe by the abbot of Osene. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 432.

John de Ledewell quit-claims to William de Schareshull his right in a messuage and one virgate of land in Little Tywe, which the latter has by the gift of John le Fuleward (?) of Niwenton Juwel. Dated at Stodlegh the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 5 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 433.

Indenture witnessing that the cause in the King's court between Walter ... of Little Tywe, plaintiff, and John, son of Robert atte Lake, defendant, has been amicably settled, concerning forest rights. Dated at Little Tywe the Wednesday next after the feast of St. ..., 8 Ed. III. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 434.

TEW (Great), HAMPTON, BARFORD, DUNSTEW, and ILBURY, co. Oxon. William Cardemaker, John Brook, master Edward Undrewode, clerk, and John Smert, grocer, sell, demise, and enfeoff William Fox of Stepill Barton in Oxon, yeoman, and Richard Fox of Dadyngton, yeoman, in all lands, tenements, &c., in Mocheltewe, Hempton, Barford, Dunstewe, and Ilbury, in co. Oxon, which were lately assigned to them by Robert Smythfeld, citizen and grocer of London. Dated 27 May, 19 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 419a.

TEW, SANDFORD, BARTON, and ROUSHAM. Licence from the King to William de Shareshull, by the payment of five marks, to exchange with the abbot and convent of Oseney 8 messuages, three cottages, one shop, one water-mill, 14 virgates of land, and 20 acres of meadow, in Little Tew, Sandford, and Oxford, for 6 messuages, one water-mill, 16 virgates of land, and six acres of meadow in Barton Odo, and Rousham. Dated at Westminster, 30 June, 24 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 438.

THENFORD, Northamptonshire. Indenture between the abbot and convent of Oseney, and the prior and convent of Coldnorton, concerning two parts of the tithes of the fee which antiently belonged to the church of St. George within the castle, Oxford, within the parish church of Theneford. Dated at Cold Norton, 20 March, 1394. [Mutilated.] [With seal of Cold Norton "Sigill' ecclesie Sancti Iohanis et Convent' de Nort'".] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 245b.

THOMLEY, co. Oxon. Aeliz Ghernon, formerly wife of Henry de Tomelee, grants to William, son of William, son of Helyas and Rohass his wife, for his service, 2s. of annual rent which the abbot of Oxenee paid annually to her in Tomelee, for the croft where she dwels after the death of her husband and one virgate of land in the same village, viz. that virgate which Thomas the clerk held with the manse, paying annually for the same one quarter of corn at Michaelmas. For this donation he gave one mark of silver. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 439.

An acknowledgment that Alice Colshyll, prioress of Gorynge, has received of the abbot of Oseney l0s. of rent for lands in Thomele. Dated at Gorynge, 4 October, 13 Hen. VII. [With seal, broken and indistinct.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 246b.

THORNTON-LE-STREET, Yorkshire. Mutilated decree of judges appointed by the Pope [Alexander IV] concerning the right to the tithes of the mill of Kilvinton in the parish of Thornton, decreeing annual payment by the abbey of Eglestone of half a mark to the master and brethren of a hospi. (1249). [The papal letter is dated at Lyons 12 Cal. May, an. VII] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 204.

Thornton, Bucks. Commission addressed to John, bp. of Lincoln, by K. Edward II, concerning a claim to a fourth part of the church of Thornton by Oseney, in a suit between Walter the parson and Malcolm de Chastilon, that the church is valued at eight marks besides a pension of 10s. paid to Oseney. With the return of the bishop, dated at Buckden, 5 Kl. July, 1309. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 205.

Sentence of the court of Canterbury adjudging two parts of the great tithes from the ancient demesne of 'Thornethone' to the abbey of Oseney against a claim by Elgas the rector. Dated at London, 15 June, 1319. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 206.

THRUP. John Frome of Buckingham appoints Thomas Langeport and Robert Purdy, his attornies, to deliver to the abbot and convent of Oseney six messuages, six virgates of land, and six acres of meadow, together with 1s. 7d. annual rents in [Thrupp]. Dated at Oxford, 16 Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 440.

Indenture between John Bokeland, abbot, and the convent of Oseney of one part, and Robert Wych, parson of Hyntton, Salisbury diocese, of the other part, witnesseth, that the abbot and convent grant to farm to the said Robert, for the term of his life, all their lands and tenements in Thrope, near Cudlington, which they had of the gift of the said
Robert, John Frome, and John Worton, paying at the feast of the Nativity of St. John Bapt. one rose. Dated at Oseney, 8 Sept., 16 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 441.

TOWCESTER, co. Northampton. Mutilated account of receipts and payments from the tithes of Towcester with reference to the grant to the Pope for six years. Temp. Ed. I. [See also Ch. 26 and Ch. 26b.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 27.

An acknowledgment by Gifferd de Vezana, canon of Cambray, nuncio of the Pope, has received of the abbot and convent of Oseney, by the hands of Hugh de Cumpton, £8 sterling from the tenth of Towcester, for the first 3 of the six years in which the tenth was granted as a subsidy for the Holy Land to Pope Boniface when he held the said church as cardinal; according to an account by the bishop of Lincoln of the sum of £584 11s. 11 3/4d, as contained in Ch. 27. Dated 14 Kl. Aug., 1299. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 26b.

TURKDEN. Robert Bel de Stowell grants to Robert le Bel, his son, one virgate of land in Turkedene, with appurtenances, which Robert de Toreni gave to him, paying annually the service due to the chief lord of the fee, viz. 1 lb. of cummin, which Sara relict of Rondulf the smith holds for her life. Witness. Thomas, abbot of Winchcombe. (c. 1221-31.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 224.

Robert de Toreny grants to the church and canons of Oseney a confirmation of the gift which William, son of Henry, his father, made to them of the church of Turkden, in frankalmoigne. (c. 1240.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 225.

An indenture witnessing that John Benfiz, bailiff of the abbot of Oseney at Turkden, has been removed from his office, and Henry in le Herne has been appointed bailiff in his place, together with an inventory of goods handed over to his custody. Dated Tuesday on the feast of St. Michael, 29 Ed. III. [Mutilated and partly obliterated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 442.

TUSMORE. Notarial certificate of the acknowledgment by sir Roger de Cotesford of the right of the abbot of Oseney to two parts of the tithes of certain furzes which were Maurice Daundelay's, lying and growing in the fields of Tursmere. Dated 1374. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 442.

UPTON. Convention between C[lement], the abbot, and convent of Oseney of one part, and Harding de Upton of the other part, by which the said abbot and convent grant to the said Harding one virgate of land in Upton, ... 2 messuages, a field, ... and ten acres of arable land, for his life, paying 6s. annually. (c. 1210-20.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 207.

Convention beween Herding de Upton, and Oseney, by which he delivers to Oseney ... acres of his land in Upton to farm, of that virgate of land which he holds of the said canons. Dated at Stanes, feast of St. John Baptist. ([12]30.) [Fragment.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 208.

Clemencia, relict of Richard de Uptun, with the counsel and consent of Henry de Dunnitun, quit-claims to William her son, the said son of Richard de Upton, all right in three acres and a half of land in the fields of Uptun. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 209.

Indenture by which the abbot and convent of Oseney demise to
Richard ... their rectory, &c. of Upton, with a croft called West crofte for ... years at an annual rent of £22. (Temp. Hen. VI.) [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 210.

At a court held at Upton, co. Berks, 5 October, 16 Hen. VII, Rich. Newington took of the lord one messuage and half a virgate of land in the village and fields of Upton, lately in the tenure of William Rychemond, to have and to hold according to the custom of the manor. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 211.

WALLINGFORD, co. Berks. Richard Kent, alderman of Oxford, and Joan his wife, with the assent and consent of one another, grant to Richard Leyceter, the abbot, and convent of Oseney, the whole of their tenement situated in the parish of St. Mary the greater, Wallingford, in exchange for a shop and garden in All Saints', Oxford. Dated at Wallingford, 11 August, 1 Rich. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 151.

WANTAGE, co. Berks. Grant from Robert, [natural] son of King Henry I, with the counsel of Henry D'Oilly his brother, in frankalmoigne, to the church of Oseney, of 10 pounds worth of land in his manor of Wanenting. Witnessed Hugh de Camville. (c. 1150.) [Endorsed by Hearne as having been given to him by Reb. Edw. Lye, 2 Sept. 1730.] (Erroneously said in Monest. Angl. to be in the Cotton Library.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 152.

WATCOMBE, near Watlington. An inquiry having been directed by the Pope to be made by the abbots of Missenden and Abingdon, R., the prior of Kenilworth, whether the abbot and convent of Preaux have erected a chapel at Wadcumbe, notwithstanding the prohibition of R., archbp. of Canterbury, and to execute a decree prohibiting divine offices being celebrated there if such should be the case; witnesses on the part of the abbot and convent of Oseney having been examined, an injunction is given to Richard de Eilesberi, deputy ("vice") of the archdeacon of Oxford to prohibit all such celebration in the chapel. (c. 1190.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 451a.

A certificate from A[dam], abbot of Evesham, and E., prior of Reading, addressed to W[alter], bp. of Lincoln, concerning a cause of vexation by the canons of Oseney to sir William, knight of Hameldene, relating to the tithes of Wadecumbe, by which they release the said knight from the vexation of the said canons. (1183-84.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 455.

Osbert de Hameledene by authority of a letter of Pope Honorius III, from the abbot and convent of Oseney, in a cause trial at Oxford before S[imon], abbot of Thame and N[icholas] and R[obert], priors of Eynesham and Berncestre, concerning the tithes of the whole of his demesne of Watecumbe, acknowledges for himself and heirs that the said tithes appertain to the church of Watlington, and by this present writing grants and confirms the same to the abbot and convent of Oseney. [1216-1225.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 456.

Indenture made between the abbot and convent of Oseney of the one part, and the prior and convent of St. Frideswide of the other, witnesseth that the abbot and convent grant to the prior and convent
...(mention of "frere Rogereo Croys" as a boundary)... lying at Oxford, near a meadow of the said prior, and 17 acres ... in exchange for other land in Eton and elsewhere. Dated the Thursday next after the feast of St. Ambrose, bp., 1359. [Mutilated.] [Fragment of seal of St. Frideswide.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 445b.

Alice Frankeleyn of Watereton quit-claims to John Hauvile (?) of Curtlington and Alice his wife, all her right in all lands, fields, &c. which were Adam Frankeleyn's of Watereton, her late husband. Dated at Watereton the Monday next after the feast of St. Matthew the apostle, 8 Rich. II. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 447.

WATERETON and CUDESLOWE. Simon, the prior, and convent of St. Frideswide quit-claim to the abbot and convent of Oseney, the suit of their tenants (hominum) in Eaton and Cudeslowe, now and for ever, which suit they were accustomed to make from ancient time to their mill, which was called Hulc mill. For this renunciation the said abbot and convent remit 2s. for certain tithes of Elsefeld, and also pay to them half a mark of silver on the feast of St. Michael yearly. Witness. Vivian, son of Ralph, sheriff [1221]. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 443.

WATERPERRY. Final concord, dated at Westminster, 20 Hen. [III], concerning the right to half of the church of Pirie (Waterperry), between William, son of William, son of Elias, and John, the abbot of Oseney, by which the said William recognises the right of the abbot and convent to the half of the church, his mother Roesia de la Rokele being present. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 448.

A cause between the abbot and convent of Oseney of the one part, and Agnes de Beaufo ("Bellafago"), Richard her son, William de Miltecumbe, and Henry Mace of Watele, executors of the will of Henry de Beaufo ("Bellafago"), of the other part, concerning a mortuary of the best beast due to the abbot and convent of Oseney from Waterperry. Dated at Oxford on the morrow of St. Mary Magdalen, 1273. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 449.

An acquittance given by Roger de Newynton as executor of William de Aldebury, rector of More, and official of the archdeacon of Oxford, to the executor of William, vicar of Waterpery, and dean of Cudesdon, for the payment of 35s. Dated at Oseney, 6 Id. June, 1362. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 450.

WATLINGTON, Oxon. Judgment given in favour of Oseney by master John Cornwall, and master Robert de Melumer, in a tithe cause] between the abbot and canons of Oseney and Jordan de Hameldene, concerning the tithes of all the moveables which the same Jordan had in the parish of Watlinton, which he claims to be tithe-free on land held under the abbey of Preaux. Dated on the morrow after the synod celebrated about the feast of Michaelmas, 1192. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 451b.

William, son of Helias de Hettecumbe, grants to the church and canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, three acres of land in Watlintone, viz. one acre near Wuestorn under the way, one acre above Ikenild between the two ways, and a croft which is to the east of Ferncroft, near the house of his mother, to hold to him and his heirs, paying annually 1/2 lb. cummin. (c. 1190-1200.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 452.

Maein, son of Hugh le Brech, grants to the church of St. Mary of Wathlintone, and to the canons of Oseney, in frankalmoigne, two acres of land which the same canons had of the gift of his grandfather and father, whereof one lies in Winethorn, and another under Ikenild at Sorteforlung; also he grants to them one acre which lies near the two 'Bergas' above Bretewelle, and also a fourth part of one acre which lies 'a la flete' between Peritone and Watlintone, to hold the same for an annual rent of 12d. for all service. (c. 1200-10.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 453.

Hugh de Syresfeld grants to the abbot and convent of Oseney, one acre of land in the field of Watlintune, viz. in a culture which is called Chelhurst which Geoffrey de Syresfeld held. (c. 1220.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 454.

WAVERTON, Cheshire. Sir John de Croft, kt., son of sir Hugh de Croft, kt., records and confirms the grant made by his ancestor sir Hugh in 1191 of the tithes of his lordship of Waverton to the abbot and canons of Oseney, to be held of the priory of Tetfort. Dated October, 1289. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 214b.

WELD, co. Oxon. Convention between Geoffrey de Burton and Walter Toky of Welde, by which the said Walter lets to farm to the said Geoffrey his water and fishery, which is between the water of sir Roger de Oyli and John Pulcre, and a certain stone which is called Mulestone, for 8 years, for which the said Geoffrey gave to the said Walter 20s. (23 or 13 "...mo tercio" Hen. fil. [Joh.]) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 458.

WESTBURY. Walter Line of Westbury, son of William the carter, of Schaldeston, grants to Sibil his daughter a messuage with a curtilage adjoining, in Westbury, which he had in exchange from William, son of Osebert the smith. Dated ... the Sunday next before the feast of St. Andrew the apostle, 24 [Edw. I.] Witn. Jordan Bastard of Westbury. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 212.

Indenture between the abbot and convent of Oseney of the one part, and sir Thomas Laurence, vicar of Westbury, of the other, witnesseth that the abbot and convent have demised to T. L. their portion of the tithes of Westbury, he paying annually 23s. 4d. to hold the same so long as he continues vicar of Westbury. Dated at Oseney on the feast of St. Cuthbert, bp., 16 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 213.

Indenture between the abbot and convent of Oseney of one part, and Jordan Bastard of Westbury of the other, witnesseth that the said Jordan for six marks sterling, in hand paid, demise to the abbot and
convent for twenty years a meadow between that of the lord of Westbury and the meadow of Fulewele. Dated at [Ful]well on St. Barnabas' day, 2 Ed. [I]. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 214a.
WESTON, co. Oxon. Mutilated manor court roll, held at Weston. [Temp. Ed. II.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 459.

Henry D'Oilly, constable of the King, grants to John, the clerk of Weston, that donation which Ralph, son of William, son of Matill' [sc. Maud], made to him of 20 acres of land in Weston. For this concession the said John gave to the said Henry one mark of silver, and to Sibil his wife one besant. (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 460.

An acquittance given by sir Roger de Aumary to the abbot and convent of Oseney, for the payment of certain sums, 90 marks out of 300 marks, at certain times as by a final concord between him and them concerning two knights' fees of the manor of Weston. Dated the Thursday in Easter week, 45 Hen. III and a.d. [14]61. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 461.
Manumission of Richard ..., a serf belonging to the manor of the abbot and convent of Oseney, of Weston, from villenage, &c. Dated 14 September, 7 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 463.
Manumission of John, a serf of the manor of Weston, belonging to the abbot and convent of Oseney, from villenage, &c. Dated .. Aug. 10 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 464.

John Squyer of Weston quit-claims to Thomas Rolfe, son of William Rolfe, all his right to a messuage, &c. in Weston. Dated at Weston on the feast of St. Matthias the apostle, 12 Hen. VI. [Much defaced.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 465.

John Smyth, rector of Wendulbury, and Robert Bocher of Kyrtlington, grant to the John Walton abbot and convent of Oseney all their lands, &c. in Weston near Bicester. Dated at Weston, 20 May, 38 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 466.

WESTON and BLECHINGTON. John, rector of Ardley, remits and quit-claims all right he has in 2 1/2 acres and one rood of arable land in the fields of Weston, and one acre of meadow in the fields of Blegisdon, which he had of the gift of Matilda le Heyr of Ardley. Dated at Ardley the Thursday next after the feast of St. John ante port. lat., 21 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 462.

WOODSTOCK, CO. Oxon. At court of Portmote, held at New Woodstock, 26 January, 9 and 23 February, 15 Hen. VII, the abbot and convent of Oseney appeared and claimed to hold to themselves and their successors one tenement situate in Woodstock in the street called Schyppemerket stret, which after three proclamations according to the custom of the town of Woodstock, was allowed and enrolled. Dated 7 August, 15 Hen. VII. Will. Frutham, mayor MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 468.

YARMOUTH (Great), co. Norfolk. An acknowledgment by sir
William de Shareshull, knight, tof the receipt from John Conuten... (?) and Philippa his wife, and Adam ... by the hands of Thomas de Cobald, of five marks sterling, arrears for divers tenements in Great Yarmouth from the abbey of Oseney. Dated Sat. next before feast of ... 27 Ed. III. [Partly illegible and mutilated.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 271.

COWLEY and OXFORD. An account (heading gone) of the receipts from the chapels of St. Thomas the martyr, Oxford, and St. James, Cowley, and the expenses of the services of those two chapels and maintenance of 2 scholars of St. Mary's College, Robert Dowden and Will. Goodwyn. [Temp. Edw. III] [Mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 5.
Court roll .... Oct. 30 Hen. VI. [Partly illegible.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 9.
Bailiff's account (fragment) for some manor within Oxfordshire. [Temp. Hen. VI.] [Hanborough ["Heneburgh"], Kidlington ["Cudlington"], and Eton mentioned] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 13.

KIDLINGTON, HAMPTON, KENSINGTON, and SHIPTON. Rental of lands in the above villages. [Temp. Edw. III.] "Yis is ye rental to ye abbodes manere of Oseneye at Cudelintone, etc.." (English) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 14.

KILTEVENAN, Ireland. The account of John P...gnaunt, keeper ("custodis") of the church of Kiltevenam, from Mich., 4 Ed. III, to the same feast, 5 Ed. III. [Partly printed in Trans. of Royal archaeol. Soc. of Ireland, 1902, vol. xxxii, p. 194.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 16.

MAIDS MORTON. Roll containing transcripts and summaries of various evidences of the lands, formerly Burgan's &c. belonging to Oseney in Maids Morton, Bucks. (temp. Ed. III).
In dorso is a claim, made in August, [year omitted] 2 Rich. II, by Elinor and Edith, sisters, daughters of John de Morton, of 1 lb pepper, 1 lb cummin, and 4d., issuing from lands in Morton, &c., as descendants of William Burgan. [Mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 18.
Roll (heading torn away) of brother Robert Walden, infirmarius. [10-11 Hen. VII (?).] [Apparently, from names mentioned of the following year from Oseney Rolls, 23.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 24.
The account of ... there from the morrow of St. Michael, 12 Hen. VII, to the same feast, 13 Hen. VII. [Mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 25.

Kent Priory. Roll (heading gone) containing an account of the daily consumption of fish, meat, and corn at Tunbridge for 30 week. [Some provisions are entered as being taken from the shops at Tonebregge, Brenchesle, and Elg. There is no date of the year to be found in the roll . The writing seems to assign the date to the early time of Edw. II.]
MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 28.
Fragment of a [bailiff's ?] roll of accounts. [c. Temp. Hen. VII.] [Illegible and mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 31.
Fragment of a roll of accounts. [Temp. Hen. VII.] [Much mutilated and illegible.] (Apparently a further part of the preceding roll.) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 32.

The last membrane of a sacristants account [for wax, oil, bell-ropes, and other things used in the chapel, also salaries for clerks and chaplains]. [Thomas Hokenorton, lately abbot, mentioned.] [Temp. Ed. IV.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 38.
Roll of accounts (fragment) of payments for wine, and various receipts from manors, courts, &c., 17 Ed. III (?). [Partly illegible.] [Hugh de Plesy mentioned.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 39.
Fragment of a bailiff's farm and mill account. (c. 1300-10) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 40.
Last membrane of a bailiffs account for farm, containing stock and produces. (c. 1300-10) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 41.
Part of a bailiff's roll of account. (c. 1300) [Partly effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 42.
Part of a roll of accounts of a manor in Oxfordshire. (c. 1300) [In large part nearly effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 43.
The last membrane of a roll of expenses an. 1325. 'Summa omnium solutorum liberatorum et expensarum lxiiij li. xviij s. viij d. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 44.
Part of a roll of accounts, c. 1300, mutilated and partly obliterated, containing payments and allowances. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 45.
The last membrane of a roll of payments. [Temp. Edw. III. (?)] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 46.
Fragment of an account. [Mutilated and in great part effaced.] (c. 1400-20 (?)) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 47.
Tonbridge, Kent. One membrane of a bailiffs account, for a manor of the Priory of Tonbridge. (c. 1410-20 (?)) [Partly effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 48.
Fragment of a roll of accounts. [Temp. Hen. VI.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 49.
Part of a copy of a confirmation-charter of grants, to the abbey. [Temp. Ed. III.] [Mutilated and in part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 50.
OVYNG, STEEPLE CLAYDON, [MORTON, STOW? ... DODFORD?] and MIXBURY. Court roll for the above manors, Oct. 30 Hen. VI. [Much mutilated and in part illegible.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 51.
OXFORD. Rent roll for the year 1260. ("Rotulus de burgo Oxon anni scilicet domini M.CC.LX") MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 52.

Fragment of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, containing the rents from the parishes of St. Aldate, St. Michael, St. Cross, St. Mary Magdalen, St. Giles, and St. Clement.
(c. 1250-1260 ?) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 53.

Fragment of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, containing the parishes of [St. Mary V. ?] St. Peter in the East, St. John, St. Edward and All Saints. (c. 1260-1270 ? (or earlier)) [Indorsed by A. Wood, circa vel post 1277. ] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 54.

Portion of the rent roll for the year 1280, containing the parishes of St. Michael's, North, St. Mildred, St. Mary the Virgin, St. Michael's, South, St. Cross, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalen, and St. Thomas. ("Rotulus de burgo Oxon. anni Domini M.CC.Octag.") MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 55.
Fragment of a rent roll for the city of Oxford. (c. 1300) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 56.
Fragment of a rent roll in the city of Oxford, viz. for the parishes of St. Peter in the East, St. John, and St. Edward. [Temp. Ed. II.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 88.
Long rent roll (heading effaced) indorsed by A. Wood, as being of the year 1317. On the back is a list of quit-rents paid by the abbey out of the rents. [Partly effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 57.
"Rotulus de burgo Oxone", 18 Edw. II, [1324-25]. [Three membranes, perfect, with the quit-rents.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 58.
Rent roll (fragment) for the city of Oxford, containing the parish of St. Thomas and part of that of [St. Mary Magdalen ?], with the names of the tenants. [Temp. Ed. III.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 59.
Fragment of a rent roll of the parishes of St. Mary Magdalen, St. George, St. Edward, St. Martin and All Saints. [Temp. Edw. III.] [Mutilated, and in great part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 60.
The first part of the roll of the account of brother John ... chief cook, and collector of the rents in Oxford, from Mich. 12 Rich. II, to Mich. 13 Rich. II., [1389]. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 61.
Rent roll of the parishes of St. Martin, St. Peter le Bailey, St. John and St. Edward. [Temp. Edw. III.] [Fragment, partly effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 62.
Part of a rent roll to Mich., 3 Hen. IV, 1402, containing the parishes of St. Michael's, North, St. Mary V. and St. Peter in the east, with names of tenants. [Mutilated] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 63.

Fragment of a rent roll of lands and tenements in the parishes of St. Michael, north, and part of St. George, for Mich., 7 [Hen. IV], with names. [In the time of brother William Wendover.] [In part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 64.
Fragment of a rent roll, containing part of the parishes of St. Michael, north, and St. Mildred. Temp. Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 65.
Part of a rent roll, containing the rents from St. Peter in the East, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints,St. Martin, and St. George, with names. Temp. Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 66.

Rent roll, part of, containing rents from the parishes of St. Peter le Bailey, St. Ebbe, St. Aldate, St. Michael South, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalen, and St. George, with names. Temp. Hen. IV. [Mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 67.

Fragment of a rent roll containing the rents from the parishes of St. Mary the Virgin (part of), St. Peter in the east, St. John, and St. Edward, with names. [Temp. Hen. IV] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 68.

Part of a rent roll in the parishes of St. Mildred, St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, St. Martin, St. Peter le bailey, St. Ebbe, St. Aldate, St. Michael South, St. George, and St. John. Temp. Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 70.

Rent roll (much mutilated), and in part effaced, containing the parishes of St. Mildrith,St. Mary Virgin, St. Peter in East, St. John, St. Edward, St. Peter le Bailey, St. Aldate, St. Michael South, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalen, St. George, etc. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 71.

Fragment of a rent roll, in St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin, and St. Peter le bailey. Temp. Rich. II (?). [In large part effaced.] MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 72.

Part of a rent roll in the parishes of St. Michael's north, St. Mildred, St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, showing increase or decrease of rents "hoc anno". [Temp. Rich. II ?] [In great part obliterated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 73.
Rent roll of brother Robert (?) M... for the city of Oxford to Michaelmas, [10?] Henry VI [1431?]. [Much mutilated, and in great part effaced.] [Thomas Hokenorton, abbot.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 74.

Fragment of a roll showing the increase and decrease of rents, with the payments of quit-rents in the parishes of St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Peter le bailey, St. Ebbe, St. Aldate, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalene, and St. George. [1 Hen VI?], after 12 Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 75

Fragment of a roll, within the parishes of St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin, St. Peter le bailey, St. Ebbe, St. Aldate, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalen, and St. Thomas. Temp. Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 76.

Fragment of a roll containing payments for quit-rents and for repairs in the parishes of St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, All Saints, St. John, St. Edward, and St. Peter le bailey. Temp. Hen. IV. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 77.

The first membrane of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, containing the rents from the parishes of St. Michael north, St. Mildred, St. Mary the Virgin (part of). Made 1 Hen. V, during the time of brother Henry [Northwode], abbot. [Heading mutilated.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 78.
Rent roll for the city of Oxford in the time of abbot Henry de Northwode, perfect except that the parish of St. Thomas is wanting. 5 Hen. V, anno Domini 1417. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 77.

Fragment of a rent roll of the city of Oxford, much mutilated, containing the parishes of St. Mary the Virgin, and St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, and St. Thomas, with quit-rents. Temp. Edw. III or Rich. II. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 80.
Rent roll, anno 1449. [Slightly mutilated and in parts effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 81.
Fragment of a roll of receipts in Oxford. (c. 1400?) [In great part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 115.

Fragment of a roll in the parishes of All Saints, St. Martin, St. Peter le bailey, St. Ebbe, St. Aldate, St. Giles, St. Mary Magdalen, and St. George, with the payments for quit-rents. c. 5 Hen. VI. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 82.
Fragment of a roll of rents and payments within the city of Oxford. [21 Rich. II] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 83.

Part of a rent roll of the city of Oxford [temp. Hen. VI ?], including the parishes of part of St. Mary the Virgin, St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin, and St. Peter in the bailey, with names of tenants. (c. 1400-20?) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 84.

Fragment of a roll of expenses for repairs of houses, &c. in the parishes of St. Mary the Virgin, St. Mildred, St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin, St. Ebbe's, and St. George, &c. Temp. Hen. VI. (c. 1430-50) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 85.
Part of a rent roll with decrease of rents, in Oxford, and payments for repairs, &c. [In part effaced.]. [2] Hen. VI. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 86.

Fragment of a rent roll of increase and decrease of rents, together with expenses in St. Mary the Virgin, St. Mildred, St. Peter in the east, St. John, St. Edward, All Saints, St. Martin, and St. Peter le Bailey. Temp. Hen. VI. (c. 1440-50 ?) [Mutilated and in parts effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 87.

Fragment of a roll (mutilated, and in part effaced), of proceedings in a suit between Thomas, abbot of Oseney, and Thomas Coventry and Alice his wife, concerning three messuages in the parish of St. Mary Magdalen in Oxford. 15 Hen. VI. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 89.

Translation, made temp. Hen. VIII, of the award of John [Bokyngham] the bishop of Lincoln for settling the differences between the abbot and convent of Oseney and the city of Oxford, touching the extent of their franchises in the isle of Oseney. Dated at London, 22 Feb., 50 Ed. III.
[Paper.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 90.

Fragment of an inquisition taken 47 Ed. III, to enquire by what right the abbot and convent of Oseney diverted half of the water of the river Thames, called the Bakwater, from the King's mill. [In part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 91.
Fragment of a bailiff's account, apparently of a manor in Bucks or Northant. (c. 1280-1300) [Mutilated and in great part effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 93.
See Ch. 430. MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 99.

See MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 546.
MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 102.

See MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 545.
MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 103.
See MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 444. Also in Denholm-Young, p. 15 MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 104.

WIKEDIVE. Part of a roll of a law-plea concerning an annual pension of 23s. 4d., the third part of the tithes of Wykedyve, retained by Robert Lyndeley, parson of the same church, the same being due to the abbot of Oseney. (c. 1505) MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 113.
Fragment of a court roll of Weston in the time of Thomas Grey, 2nd Marquess of Dorset (1513) [Entirely effaced.] MS. Rolls Oxon. Oseney 114.
OSENEY. Fragment of a charter of a grant of lands in Twicurs (Twyecross, Leicesterhire). (c. 1210-20.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 565.

Portion of the will of [Henry de Chaddesden], archdeacon of Leicester, appointing Thomas [de Cudlinton], abbot of Oseney, his executor, and leaving his library of books, goods, &c. to various persons, and
considerable benefactions to Oseney. Among the legatees are John de Belvers, rector of Kyrkeby Mallory, Richard de Medmenham, rector of Upton-on-Severn, Philip, chaplain of Wyrthorp, near Staunford, John, chaplain of Epwell, Peter, rector of Nayleston, Alexander, rector of Shakerstone, &c. (c. 1354.) MS. Ch. Oxon. Oseney 566.
Fragment of an account, of rent-receipts and expences 30 [Hen. VI]. Locality unknown. MS. Ch. Oxon. 209.

Mandate from King Edward VI, dated at Westminster, 10 Nov., 6th of his reign, to William Hyde, esq., late sheriff of Oxon and Berks, to deliver the rolls, &c. to Leonard Chamberlain, esq., who has been appointed sheriff by letters patent. MS. Ch. Oxon. 210.
